example.text:
[PHARMACIST]: Hi Dr. Lee, I wanted to speak with you about Mr. James Carter, who’s being discharged today. He’s being started on warfarin for atrial fibrillation post-op, and I’m organising his discharge medications and follow-up.
[DOCTOR]: Thanks. What’s the current plan?
[PHARMACIST]: He’s had two doses of warfarin so far—5 mg on Day 1 and 3 mg yesterday. His INR this morning was 1.6, so still subtherapeutic. I’ve charted 3 mg again today, and we’ll need to arrange ongoing INR monitoring through his GP or local pathology service.
[DOCTOR]: Okay. Has the GP been contacted?
[PHARMACIST]: Not yet. I was going to ask if you’d like to send a discharge summary with a note to the GP to monitor INR every 2–3 days initially, and adjust dosing as needed. I’ll also include a warfarin education leaflet and a yellow book for tracking.
[DOCTOR]: Yes, please include that in the discharge paperwork. Has he been counselled?
[PHARMACIST]: Yes, I’ve spoken with him about, Dietary interactions (especially vitamin K), Bleeding risks, Signs to report (e.g. bruising, blood in urine/stool), Avoiding NSAIDs and alcohol, He’s aware and has agreed to follow up with his GP.
[DOCTOR]: Great. Any other meds to note?
[PHARMACIST]: He’s also on, Metoprolol 25 mg BD, Atorvastatin 40 mg nocte, Paracetamol PRN, No known drug allergies.
[DOCTOR]: Perfect. I’ll finalise the discharge summary and include the INR plan. Thanks for organising everything.
[PHARMACIST]: No problem. I’ll send the warfarin pack with him and notify the GP clinic once he’s discharged.

[RECOVERY_NURSE]: Hi, I’m handing over Mr. Daniel Hayes, 67 years old, just returned from the cath lab following a coronary angiogram. He’s being transferred back to CCU for ongoing monitoring.
[CCU_NURSE]: Thanks. How did the procedure go?
[RECOVERY_NURSE]: Procedure was uneventful. No stents placed today—angiogram was diagnostic only. He still has the femoral sheath in situ, and it needs to be transduced for haemodynamic monitoring. His heart rate is low, sitting around 48 bpm, so we’re keeping a close eye on it.
[CCU_NURSE]: Okay. What are his current vitals?
[RECOVERY_NURSE]: BP: 110/68, HR: 48 bpm, sinus bradycardia, RR: 16, SpO?: 97% on room air, Temp: 36.6°C, He’s alert and orientated, but a bit tired post-procedure.
[CCU_NURSE]: Any lines or medications?
[RECOVERY_NURSE]: Yes, a Femoral sheath – still in place, not yet transduced, IV cannula in left forearm, No IV infusions running currently, no sedation required post-procedure and probably has some usual meds
[CCU_NURSE]: Any pain or bleeding?
[RECOVERY_NURSE]: No active bleeding. Puncture site is clean and dressed. No complaints of pain. He’s on bed rest, and we’ve reinforced strict leg immobilisation.
[CCU_NURSE]: Any medications charted?
[CCU_NURSE]: Thanks. I’ll get the sheath transduced and continue monitoring his HR closely.
[RECOVERY_NURSE]: Perfect. Let me know if anything changes. All documentation is up to date.

example.text:
[RECOVERY_NURSE]: Hi, I’m handing over Mr. Thomas Nguyen, 74 years old, just returned from theatre after a urethral dilation and bladder washout. He’s stable post-procedure and ready for transfer to the ward.
[WARD_NURSE]: Thanks. Can you give me a quick summary?
[RECOVERY_NURSE]: Sure. He was admitted with acute urinary retention and a history of benign prostatic hyperplasia. He had some clinical deterioration pre-op—low BP, reduced urine output, and confusion—but he’s responded well to treatment. He’s now passing urine via IDC, and output is improving.
[WARD_NURSE]: Vitals?
[RECOVERY_NURSE]: His BP: 112/70, HR: 88 bpm, RR: 18, SpO?: 97% on room air, Temp: 37.4°C, Urine output: 120 mL in the last hour
[WARD_NURSE]: Any lines or attachments?
[RECOVERY_NURSE]: Yes he has an IDC draining clear urine, an IV cannula in left forearm, No infusions running currently and Oxygen via nasal prongs earlier, now weaned off
[WARD_NURSE]:
Any medications charted?
[RECOVERY_NURSE]: He’s on Paracetamol 1g QID, Gentamicin IV stat dose given in theatre, PRN oxycodone and IV fluids were running intra-op, now ceased
[WARD_NURSE]: Any communication needs?
[RECOVERY_NURSE]: No, he’s English-speaking, fully alert and orientated. He’s a bit tired but understands what’s happening.
[RECOVERY_NURSE]: Hi Mr. Nguyen, this is your ward nurse, she’ll be looking after you now. You’re doing well after your procedure.
[PATIENT]: Thanks. I feel a bit groggy but better than before. Am I going back to my room now?
[WARD_NURSE]: Yes, we’ll get you settled in shortly. I’ll keep checking your blood pressure and make sure everything’s comfortable. If you need anything, just press the call bell.
[PATIENT]: Okay, thank you.
[RECOVERY_NURSE]:He’s due for post-op obs in 30 minutes, and the IDC needs to be monitored closely. Urology team will review later today.
[WARD_NURSE]: Perfect. I’ll take it from here.

[RECOVERY_NURSE]:
Hi, I’m handing over Mr. Thomas Nguyen, 74 years old, transferring to your ward post-procedure. He had a urethral dilation and bladder washout under general anaesthetic due to acute urinary retention and suspected obstructive uropathy.
[WARD_NURSE]: Thanks. How did the procedure go?
[RECOVERY_NURSE]: It went smoothly. No complications in theatre. He’s now stable but needs close monitoring due to recent deterioration pre-op—he was hypotensive and oliguric. He’s now passing urine via IDC, and output is improving.
[WARD_NURSE]: Vitals?
[RECOVERY_NURSE]: BP: 112/70, HR: 88 bpm, RR: 18, SpO?: 97% on room air, Temp: 37.4°C, Urine output: 120 mL in the last hour
[WARD_NURSE]: Any lines or attachments?
[RECOVERY_NURSE]: Yes: he has an IDC draining with clear urine, an IV cannula in left forearm, there are No infusions running currently and Oxygen via nasal prongs earlier, now weaned off
[WARD_NURSE]: Any medications charted?
[RECOVERY_NURSE]: He’s on: Paracetamol 1g QID, Gentamicin IV stat dose given in theatre, PRN oxycodone and IV fluids were running intra-op, now ceased.
[WARD_NURSE]: Any communication needs?
[RECOVERY_NURSE]: Yes, he’s from a Vietnamese-speaking background and has limited English. Interpreter has been requested for ward rounds. His son is bilingual and will be visiting later today.
[WARD_NURSE]: Thanks. Any outstanding tasks?
[RECOVERY_NURSE]: He’s due for post-op obs in 30 minutes, and the IDC needs to be monitored closely. Urology team will review later today. He’s alert but tired.
[WARD_NURSE]: Perfect. I’ll get him settled and continue monitoring.
[RECOVERY_NURSE]: Great. Let me know if anything changes. All documentation is up to date.

example.text:
[DIETITIAN]: Hi, I’m handing over Mr. Robert King, 58 years old, currently Day 3 post-abdominal surgery. He’s receiving Total Parenteral Nutrition (TPN) via a central line due to nil oral intake and delayed return of gut function.
[NURSE]: Thanks. What’s the current TPN plan?
[DIETITIAN]: He’s on a standard TPN formulation with electrolytes, glucose, amino acids, and lipids. It’s running over 24 hours via central line, and we’re monitoring daily bloods—including U&Es, LFTs, glucose, and triglycerides. His fluid balance and weight should be tracked daily.
[NURSE]: Any specific concerns?
[DIETITIAN]: Yes, he’s at risk of refeeding syndrome, so we’ve started thiamine supplementation and are watching his phosphate and magnesium levels closely. So far, electrolytes are stable.
[NURSE]: Is he tolerating the TPN well?
[DIETITIAN]: Yes, no signs of intolerance. No nausea or vomiting. He’s alert and understands the plan. We’ve discussed the importance of not disconnecting the line and keeping the TPN pump running continuously.
[NURSE]: (to patient) Hi Mr. King, I’ll be looking after you today. How are you feeling?
[PATIENT]: A bit tired, but okay. I’m just hoping I can eat again soon.
[DIETITIAN]: We’re aiming to reassess gut function in the next 48 hours. Once bowel sounds return and surgical team clears it, we’ll start clear fluids, then build up gradually.
[NURSE]: I’ll monitor his obs, fluid balance, and bloods. Anything else?
[DIETITIAN]: Just make sure the TPN line stays dedicated—no meds or flushes through it. And please notify me if there are any signs of infection, line issues, or abnormal blood results.
[NURSE]: Will do. Thanks for the handover.

example.text:
[NURSE]: Hi Dr. Patel, thanks for coming. I’d like you to review Ms. Evelyn Grant in bed 9. She’s a 68-year-old admitted with a urinary tract infection, now deteriorating—likely urosepsis.
[DOCTOR]: What’s happening?
[NURSE]: Over the past few hours, she’s become increasingly tachycardic and febrile. Her Q-ADDS score is 6, which triggered escalation. She’s also more confused than her baseline—normally oriented but now disoriented to time and place.
[DOCTOR]: Can you give me her latest observations?
[NURSE]: BP: 98/62, HR: 112 bpm, RR: 22, Temp: 38.6°C, SpO?: 95% on room air, Conscious state: Alert but confused, Q-ADDS score: 6 (HR + Temp + RR + confusion)
[DOCTOR]: Has she had any recent bloods or cultures?
[NURSE]: Yes. Bloods were taken this morning: WCC: 14.2, CRP: 98, Creatinine: 102 (baseline ~85) Urine sample: Sent, we are waiting results Lactate: Not yet done—would you like it ordered?
[DOCTOR]: Any IV access?
[NURSE]: No current vascular access. She had a cannula yesterday, but it was removed due to tissuing. I can insert a new one now.
[DOCTOR]: What’s her fluid balance?
[NURSE]: Input (last 24h): ~1200 mL (oral + IV), Output: ~600 mL urine, no vomiting or diarrhoea, Net balance: +600 mL, Urine output: Reduced over last 6 hours—only 100 mL
[DOCTOR]: Allergy status?
[NURSE]: Documented penicillin allergy—rash and swelling previously.
[DOCTOR]: Current medications?
[NURSE]: Paracetamol 1g QID, IV fluids: Normal saline at 100 mL/hr, No antibiotics yet—awaiting review due to allergy
[DOCTOR]: Okay. I’ll assess her now. Let’s insert a cannula, take a lactate, and start IV ceftriaxone and gentamicin. We’ll monitor closely and consider AMU transfer if she worsens.
[NURSE]: I’ll insert the cannula, draw the lactate, and prep the antibiotics. I’ll also notify AMU if her Q-ADDS increases or confusion worsens.

preds.quote: Okay. I’ll assess her now. Let’s insert a cannula, take a lactate, and start IV ceftriaxone and gentamicin. We’ll monitor closely and consider AMU transfer if she worsens.

preds.label: RECOMMENDATION
preds.quote: I’ll insert the cannula, draw the lactate, and prep the antibiotics. I’ll also notify AMU if her Q-ADDS increases or confusion worsens.

example.text:
[NURSE]: Hi Dr. Nguyen, I need you to review Ms. Lara Bennett in bed 5. She’s a 56-year-old patient with a known history of epilepsy. She had a tonic-clonic seizure about 20 minutes ago on the ward. It lasted approximately 90 seconds and she’s now post-ictal—drowsy but rousable.
[DOCTOR]: Thanks. Is she stable now?
[NURSE]:Yes, she’s breathing spontaneously and maintaining her airway. No signs of trauma or tongue injury. She’s currently on 4-hourly neuro obs. Her latest vitals are:BP: 138/84, HR: 92 bpm, RR: 16, Temp: 36.9°C, SpO?: 98% on room air, GCS: 13,Q-ADDS score: 4 (GCS + seizure)
[DOCTOR]: Any IV access?
[NURSE]: Yes, she has a patent IV cannula in her left forearm. No IV fluids running currently—she’s tolerating oral intake. No signs of dehydration.
[DOCTOR]: Any allergies?
[NURSE]: Yes, she has a documented allergy to phenytoin—rash and dizziness previously.
[DOCTOR]: Is she catheterised?
[NURSE]: Yes, she has an indwelling catheter (IDC) in place for monitoring. Output has been normal—clear urine, ~300 mL over the last 4 hours.
[DOCTOR]: Any recent bloods?
[NURSE]: Yes, FBC and electrolytes were taken this morning: Hb: 128, WCC: 7.4, Platelets: 240, Na: 136, K: 4.2, Creatinine: 76, No major abnormalities.
[DOCTOR]: Has the family been informed?
[NURSE]: Yes, I’ve spoken to her daughter. She’s on her way in and aware of the situation. I’ve reassured her that Lara is stable but still recovering.
[DOCTOR]: Thanks. Let’s continue neuro obs, monitor for any further seizures, and review her antiepileptic regimen. If she has another seizure or her GCS drops, please escalate immediately.
[NURSE]: I’ll keep monitoring and update you if anything changes.

example.text:
[Outgoing Nurse]: Hi, I’m handing over Mrs. Elaine Morris in bed 6. She’s an 84-year-old patient with reduced mobility following a recent pneumonia admission. She has a stage 2 pressure injury on her right hip.
[Incoming Nurse]: Thanks. What’s the current condition of the wound?
[Outgoing Nurse]: It’s a shallow ulcer with partial thickness skin loss. The wound bed is moist but clean, with no signs of infection. There’s mild erythema around the edges. The wound care nurse reviewed it this morning and recommended continuing with Allevyn Gentle Border dressing.
[Incoming Nurse]: How often does it need changing?
[Outgoing Nurse]: Every 3 days unless soiled or lifting. The next dressing change is due on Friday. We’re documenting progress in the wound chart and taking weekly photos for review.
[Incoming Nurse]: What’s her Waterlow score?
[Outgoing Nurse]: Waterlow score is 18, so she’s at high risk. She’s on a pressure-relieving mattress and we’re repositioning her every 2 hours.
[Incoming Nurse]: Any other relevant care?
[Outgoing Nurse]: Yes:  she has No IV access currently, her Oral intake is adequate, there’s No IDC, but she is continent of urine and bowels, Pain score is 1/10 at rest, no analgesia required, Skin integrity checks are ongoing, no other areas of concern
[Incoming Nurse]: Thanks. I’ll continue the pressure care, monitor the wound, and follow the dressing schedule.

example.text:
[NURSE]: Hi, I’m handing over Mr. David Lang in bed 11. He’s a 71-year-old patient admitted yesterday following a left-sided ischemic stroke. He’s currently stable but has significant right-sided weakness and difficulty with coordination, especially upper limb function.
[OCCUPATIONAL THERAPIST]: Thanks. What’s his current level of function?
[NURSE]: He’s alert and orientated, GCS 15. He’s mobilising with assistance but struggling with feeding, grooming, and dressing tasks. He’s right-hand dominant, which is now affected. He would benefit from an OT assessment for functional support and adaptive equipment.
[OCCUPATIONAL THERAPIST]: Any positioning or pressure care?
[NURSE]: Yes, we’re using 30-degree lateral tilt positioning to support his hemiplegic side and prevent pressure injury. He’s on a pressure-relieving mattress and repositioned every 2 hours.
[OCCUPATIONAL THERAPIST]: Any IV access or medications?
[NURSE]: He has a 20G IV cannula in his left forearm—patent, no fluids running.

[OCCUPATIONAL THERAPIST]: What about nutrition and hydration?
[NURSE]: He’s on a soft diet with thickened fluids Level 2 as per speech pathology.
Fluid balance chart shows: Input (last 24h): ~1600 mL, Output: ~1400 mL (urine), total balance: of 200 mL. He’s tolerating oral intake well with supervision.
[OCCUPATIONAL THERAPIST]: Any bowel issues?
[NURSE]: He opened his bowels this morning—formed stool, no concerns. Charted daily bowel monitoring.
[OCCUPATIONAL THERAPIST]: Thanks. I’ll assess his ADLs and see what supports we can put in place.
[NURSE]: Thanks. Let me know if you need assistance during the assessment or if any equipment needs to be ordered.

example.text:
[NURSE]: Hi, I’m handing over Mrs. Emily Carter, a 38-year-old patient who was admitted three days ago following a manic episode. She’s now been newly diagnosed with bipolar disorder and is being discharged today. I’d like to arrange home supports to help her transition safely.
[SOCIAL WORKER]: Thanks. Can you tell me about her current situation?
[NURSE]: She lives with her husband and three children aged 4, 7, and 12, plus a dog. Her husband is supportive but understandably overwhelmed. He’s asked for help managing the household while Emily stabilises. She’s currently well but still adjusting to the diagnosis.
[SOCIAL WORKER]: What kind of supports do you think she’ll need?
[NURSE]: She’ll benefit from: Domestic assistance (light cleaning, laundry, meal prep), Childcare support during the day, especially for the younger children, Mental health outreach for medication adherence and mood monitoring, Education for the family around bipolar disorder and crisis planning. Possibly pet care support if her condition fluctuates
[SOCIAL WORKER]: Any safety concerns?
[NURSE]: No current risks identified. She’s engaging well, has insight, and is compliant with treatment. Her husband is aware of early warning signs and has contact details for crisis support.
[SOCIAL WORKER]: What’s her medication plan?
[NURSE]:
She’s been started on: Lithium carbonate 400 mg BD, Quetiapine 300 mg nocte, PRN lorazepam 1 mg – not used in the last 48 hours, she’ll need regular lithium level monitoring and follow-up with the community mental health team.
[SOCIAL WORKER]: Thanks. I’ll organise a home support package and liaise with the mental health team and family services.
[NURSE]: Perfect. Let me know if you need anything further from the ward team.

[NURSE 1]: Hey, I’m handing over Sarah Nguyen, 29 years old, came into ED earlier today with acute abdominal pain — mainly in the right lower quadrant. She’s currently awaiting surgical review.
[NURSE 2]: Okay, thanks. What’s her current status?
[NURSE 1]: Vitals are stable — temp 37.8°C, HR 88, BP 118/76, RR 18, SpO? 99% on room air. Pain is sitting at 6/10, managed with IV analgesia. She’s nil by mouth pending review.
[NURSE 2]: Any imaging done?
[NURSE 1]: Yes, she’s had an abdominal ultrasound — inconclusive. CT abdomen is booked for this afternoon. Bloods show mild leukocytosis, CRP elevated. Urine is clear, pregnancy test negative.
[NURSE 2]: Any IV access?
[NURSE 1]: Yep, 20G in the left antecubital fossa — patent. She’s had IV fluids and analgesia. No known allergies.
[NURSE 2]: Any behavioural concerns?
[NURSE 1]: No concerns. She’s alert, oriented, and coping well. Just anxious about the possibility of surgery.
[NURSE 2]: Got it. Anything else I need to follow up?
[NURSE 1]: Just keep an eye on her pain and nausea. Surgical team should be around shortly. Let me know if anything changes.

example.text:
[Outgoing Nurse]: Hi, I’m handing over Mrs. Dorothy Lane in bed 5. She’s an 83-year-old patient admitted with a left neck of femur fracture following a fall at home. She’s post-op day 1 following internal fixation. She’s currently confused, intermittently orientated, and requires full assistance with care.
[Incoming Nurse]: Thanks. What’s her current Q-ADDS score?
[Outgoing Nurse]: Her Q-ADDS score is 5—due to confusion, elevated respiratory rate, and low urine output. Latest observations: BP: 118/72, HR: 96 bpm, RR: 22, Temp: 36.9°C, SpO?: 95% on room air, she’s Alert but confused.
[Incoming Nurse]: Any pressure area concerns?
[Outgoing Nurse]: Yes, she has a chronic venous leg ulcer on her right lower leg. It’s being dressed with Iodosorb and a foam dressing, reviewed by wound care yesterday. No sacral or heel breakdown noted. She’s on a pressure-relieving mattress and being repositioned every 2 hours.
[Incoming Nurse]: Is she continent?
[Outgoing Nurse]: No, she’s incontinent of urine and has an IDC in place—draining clear urine, ~400 mL over the last 6 hours. She’s also on a bowel chart—no bowel movement today, last opened bowels yesterday.
[Incoming Nurse]: Any vascular obs?
[Outgoing Nurse]: Yes, we’re doing neurovascular obs on the affected limb: Sensation: Intact, Movement: Limited due to pain, Cap refill: less than 2 seconds, Pedal pulses: Present, Skin temp: Warm.
[Incoming Nurse]: Any IV access or medications?
[Outgoing Nurse]: She has a 20G cannula in her right forearm, patent.
Medications include: IV Cefazolin 1g TDS, Paracetamol 1g QID, PRN Endone 2.5–5 mg Enoxaparin 40 mg SC daily, No known drug allergies.
[Incoming Nurse]: Thanks. I’ll continue pressure care, monitor her Q-ADDS, and update wound and fluid charts.

example.text:
[NURSE]: Hi Dr. Singh, I need to speak with you about Mr. Jason Cole in bed 7. He’s a 49-year-old patient admitted yesterday with a non-ST elevation myocardial infarction (NSTEMI). He’s now requesting to self-discharge against medical advice.
[DOCTOR]: Okay. What’s prompting the request?
[NURSE]: He’s frustrated and says he “feels fine” and wants to go home. He’s been arguing with staff and mentioned needing to “sort things out” with his partner. He’s also expressed discomfort with being in hospital and says he doesn’t want to stay another night.
[DOCTOR]: Any safety concerns?
[NURSE]: Yes. He’s still on aspirin and enoxaparin and has not yet had his cardiology review. He’s a daily smoker and disclosed regular cannabis use. He’s currently on 2 L oxygen via nasal prongs, with SpO? sitting around 93%. He’s intermittently short of breath and still reporting mild chest tightness.
[DOCTOR]: What are his latest observations?
[NURSE]: BP: 132/84, HR: 102 bpm, RR: 20, Temp: 36.8°C, SpO?: 93% on 2 L O? and Q-ADDS score: 6 (due to HR, SpO?, and chest symptoms)
[DOCTOR]: Has he been informed of the risks?
[NURSE]: I’ve explained the risks of leaving before cardiology clearance, including potential for arrhythmia or further cardiac events. He’s aware but says he’s “not staying.” I’ve started the Against Medical Advice documentation and flagged it with the nurse unit manager.
[DOCTOR]: Thanks. I’ll speak with him directly and assess capacity. If he’s determined to leave, we’ll need to complete the discharge summary and safety netting advice.
[NURSE]:
Understood. I’ll keep monitoring and let you know if his condition changes.

example.text:
[Outgoing Nurse]: Hi, I’m handing over Mr. Kyle Jensen in bed 3. He’s a 29-year-old male admitted through ED last night following a stab wound to the left lower abdomen. He’s currently stable but requires ongoing wound care and IV medications.
[Incoming Nurse]: Thanks. What’s the current status of the wound?
[Outgoing Nurse]: The wound is approximately 4 cm in length, deep but not penetrating any major organs. It was cleaned and sutured in ED. There’s mild swelling and bruising around the site, but no signs of active bleeding or infection. Dressing is intact and due for review this afternoon.
[Incoming Nurse]: Any neurovascular concerns?
[Outgoing Nurse]: Neurovascular obs are normal his Sensation and movement in lower limbs are intact, the Capillary refill less than 2 seconds, and there are No signs of vascular compromise.
[Incoming Nurse]: What medications is he on?
[Outgoing Nurse]: He’s currently on: IV Ceftriaxone 1g daily, IV Paracetamol 1g QID, PRN Morphine 2.5–5 mg SC for pain he has No known drug allergies.
[Incoming Nurse]: Any other monitoring?
[Outgoing Nurse]: Yes: a Fluid Balance Chart: Input ~1200 mL, Output ~900 mL (urine via voiding), he has a Q-ADDS score: Currently 3 (due to pain and elevated HR) His vitals are stable. 
[Incoming Nurse]: Any psychosocial concerns?
[Outgoing Nurse]: He’s cooperative but anxious. Police have been notified due to the nature of the injury. No visitors currently. Social work referral has been made.
[Incoming Nurse]: Thanks. I’ll continue wound care, monitor his IV therapy, and update his charts.

example.text:
NURSE: Dr. Lee, Mr. Matthews arrested about 40 minutes ago. We initiated CPR immediately and followed the ALS protocol. He was in asystole throughout. Despite full resuscitation efforts, we were unable to regain a pulse. Time of death was recorded at 11:42 AM.
DOCTOR: Thanks for the update. Were the family contacted?
NURSE: Yes, his wife and daughter are here now. They’re in the quiet room. I’ve let them know there was a serious deterioration, but they don’t know he’s passed yet.
DOCTOR: Alright. Let’s speak with them together. I’ll lead the conversation, and you can support with any nursing or practical details.

example.text:
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Good morning, Ms. Bennett. I’m Jack, and I’ll be your nurse for today. We’ll do a quick bedside handover with my colleague, if that’s okay.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Hi, Ms. Bennett. This is the nurse taking over for the day. Could you please confirm your full name?
[PATIENT]: Rachel Bennett.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Thank you. This is Ms. Rachel Bennett in Bed 2, Room 9, aged 52, under Dr. Wallace, Oncology Consultant.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Ms. Bennett is currently receiving cycle 3 of chemotherapy for breast cancer. She’s had mild nausea overnight, managed with antiemetics. Her vitals are stable, and she’s tolerating oral fluids. Bloods were taken this morning for routine monitoring.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She’s expressed feeling emotionally overwhelmed and worried about managing work and home responsibilities during treatment. A social worker referral was made, and they’re scheduled to visit later this morning.
[SOCIAL WORKER]: Hi Rachel, I’m Priya, one of the hospital social workers. I understand you’re going through a lot right now, and I’m here to support you. Is it okay if we talk for a few minutes?
[PATIENT]: Yes, please. I’ve been struggling a bit.
[SOCIAL WORKER]: Thank you. I know chemotherapy can be physically and emotionally exhausting. You mentioned concerns about work and home—can you tell me a bit more about what’s been difficult?
[PATIENT]: I’m a single mum, and I’ve had to take time off work. I’m worried about bills and keeping things stable for my daughter.
[SOCIAL WORKER]: That’s completely understandable. We can explore options for financial support, community services, and counselling. I can also help connect you with support groups for women going through similar experiences. Would that be helpful?
[PATIENT]: Yes, I think so. I just don’t know where to start.
[SOCIAL WORKER]: That’s okay—I'll walk you through it. You’re not alone in this, and we’ll make sure you have the support you need.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: I’ll check back in shortly, Ms. Bennett, and coordinate with Priya and Dr. Wallace’s team. Please use the call bell if you need anything.

example.text:
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Good morning, Mr. Davies. I’m Jack, and I’ll be your nurse for today. We’ll just do a quick bedside handover with my colleague, if that’s okay.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Hi, Mr. Davies. This is Emma the nurse taking over for the day. Could you please confirm your full name?
[PATIENT]: Michael Davies.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Thank you. And your date of birth? [PATIENT]: First July 1985. [OUTGOING_NURSE]: And your URN on the armband is 231879, which is what I have on the chart. So, Mr. Davies is under Dr. Kumar from Infectious Diseases — who I think will be the consultant covering this week. Mr. Davies was admitted yesterday with what seems to be acute gastroenteritis, most likely secondary to rotavirus infection. He’s currently being barrier nursed in isolation. Full PPE is required before entering — though I think they were short on gowns earlier, so check the supply trolley just in case. He’s on contact precautions, given the transmission risk.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He’s had several episodes of diarrhoea overnight — not sure how many. Managed with oral rehydration and IV fluids. No vomiting that I’m aware of. Stool sample was sent and the initial report suggests rotavirus, but the full panel isn’t back yet.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He’s tolerating small sips of water and bits of dry toast this morning. No abdominal pain reported, though he mentioned feeling “a little off” earlier. Continence aids are in use, and environmental services were notified for enhanced cleaning last night, but I’m not completely sure if they’ve been through yet.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Mr. Davies, how are you feeling this morning? Any nausea or cramping?
[PATIENT]: A bit tired, but no pain. Just still needing the bathroom a lot.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Okay, thanks. He’s aware of the need to remain in isolation and has mostly been cooperative with infection control steps. No visitors allowed at this stage, though I think his partner’s been trying to contact the ward. Dr. Kumar should be reviewing later today — I’m not sure of the exact time yet.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Great, thank you. I’ll keep monitoring his fluids, stool frequency, and general symptoms, and check in again after the review. If there’s any issue with supplies or isolation process, I’ll raise it with infection control.
[PATIENT]: No problem.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Thanks, Mr. Davies. Please use your call bell if you need anything. I’ll be finishing up my shift shortly.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks, I’ll be back soon to recheck your obs and update your chart.

example.text:
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Good morning, Mr. Reynolds. I’m Jack, and I’ll be your nurse for today. We’ll do a quick bedside handover with my colleague, if that’s okay.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Hi, Mr. Reynolds. This is the nurse taking over for the day. Could you please confirm your full name?
[PATIENT]: Thomas Reynolds.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Thank you. This is Mr. Thomas Reynolds in Bed 3, Room 8, aged 71, under Dr. Lim, Cardiothoracic Surgeon.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Mr. Reynolds is Day 1 post-op from an aortic valve replacement. He returned from theatre yesterday afternoon and was transferred to the cardiac surgical ward overnight. He’s currently on telemetry monitoring. Vitals have remained stable. He’s receiving supplemental oxygen via nasal prongs at 2L/min.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Pain is being managed with PCA (fentanyl), and he’s tolerating sips of water. Chest drain output overnight was 120 mL serosanguinous, within expected range. No signs of bleeding or infection. He’s been assisted to sit up in bed with physiotherapy this morning.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Mr. Reynolds, how are you feeling this morning? Any pain or dizziness?
[PATIENT]: A bit sore, but I’m okay. Just tired.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Pain score was 4/10 earlier. He’s alert and oriented. No nausea or vomiting. Surgical site dressing is intact. ECG shows sinus rhythm. Bloods taken this morning—awaiting results.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: I’ll follow up with the surgical team and physio and check your bloods once they’re back. Is there anything you need before we finish handover?
[PATIENT]: No, I’m fine for now.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Please use the call bell if you need anything. I’ll leave you in good hands.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: I’ll be back shortly to check your observations and review your chart, Mr. Reynolds.

[PATIENT]: I’m okay for now, thanks.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Hi Rhonda, this is Sam, the day nurse who’ll be looking after you.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Hi Rhonda, nice to meet you. We’ll just do a quick bedside handover together.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Rhonda, could you please tell us your full name and date of birth?
[PATIENT]: I’m Rhonda McKenzie. Date of birth is the 12th of May.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks, Rhonda. I’ll just check your wristband… great, details match your IV cannula is due to be changed today.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: So, this is Rhonda McKenzie, 24 years old, admitted for investigation of breathing disorders with an overnight sleep study.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: History-wise, she reports new snoring noted by her boyfriend and feeling tired despite getting about nine hours of sleep.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She’s otherwise well today. No concerns raised this shift.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay. Has a time been set for the sleep study?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Not yet. She’ll need preparation for the sleep study tonight; the sleep lab will let us know the time and come to set up.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: We will run through the prep checklist this afternoon once they call.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Rhonda, any allergies we should know about?
[PATIENT]: No, I don’t have any.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Any shortness of breath or chest discomfort right now?
[PATIENT]: No, I feel okay.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: The plan for today is routine care, await the sleep lab timing, and complete sleep-study preparation this evening.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Sounds good. Rhonda, if you need anything before they come, use the call bell. I’ll check in again shortly.
[PATIENT]: Thanks.

example.text:
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Hi Natalia, I’m Sam, I’ll be looking after you today. I’m just getting handover from Mia, is that okay?
[PATIENT]: Sure.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Thanks, Natalia. So, Bed 1 is Natalia Torres, who is 45yrs, under Dr. Cox. Diagnosis and her full history are in the chart.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She’s still febrile, temps up to 39.3, ongoing for almost two weeks. Antipyretics have been given, but the fever’s persisted.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay. Natalia, are you feeling shivery or headachy right now?
[PATIENT]: I'm just hot and tired.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She’s been coughing up small amounts of blood and having some difficulty breathing.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Natalia, has the coughing or breathlessness changed overnight?
[PATIENT]: No, about the same. Just little streaks when I cough.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Otherwise she’s self-caring and ambulant. No other changes—she’s still the same as yesterday.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay. Any new meds or interventions overnight?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: No new orders overnight aside from regular antipyretics as charted.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Natalia, are you comfortable walking to the bathroom yourself, or would you like us to walk with you?
[PATIENT]: I can walk, but I’d like someone nearby because of the breathing.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: No problem, we’ll assist. Just ring me when you need to go to the toilet.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: What is the plan for Natalia?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Continue antipyretics as ordered, monitor fever and respiratory status. Escalate to the medical team if the haemoptysis increases or her breathing becomes worse.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: I’ll keep close eye on observations and let Dr. Cox’s team know of any changes.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Natalia, is there anything you need right now—water, fan, or a cool cloth?
[PATIENT]: A cool cloth would be nice.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: I’ll bring that straight in. Thanks, Mia.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Good Morning. This is Pamela Harris Lee in bed 6. Pamela, this is Alex, the day nurse taking over from me.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Hi Pamela, nice to meet you. Is it okay if we do your bedside handover together?
[PATIENT]: Sure.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Pamela is 51 years old, admitted with an exacerbation of COPD. She’s a smoker and came in today with increased shortness of breath.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: I am just going to check your arm band, Thanks. Pamela, can you confirm your full name for me?
[PATIENT]: Pamela Harris Lee.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thank you. Any medication allergies?
[PATIENT]: No allergies that I know of.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She’s much the same as she was on arrival. She’s on her regular inhalers and nebulisers, and she’s pretty stable at the moment.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Any changes in observations or need for escalation?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: No changes. Observations are stable and there are no new concerns during my shift.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Is oxygen required?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Not at the moment she is maintaining her satuarations at 98% on room air with nebs/inhalers as charted.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Pamela, how are you feeling right now?
[PATIENT]: Still a bit short of breath, but better after the nebs.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay. I’ll make sure your inhalers and nebulisers are on time, and check in regularly with you let me know if you feel more short of breath.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: The plan for today is to continue regular puffers and nebs as charted, and  monitor her respiratory status and observations. She’s currently stable.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: I’ll review inhaler technique later and make sure she's comfortable. Pamela, press your call bell if your breathing worsens or you need anything.
[PATIENT]: Will do, thank you.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: All right, that’s everything from me.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks. I’ll take it from here.

example.text:
[OUTGOING_NURSE]:Good Morning, Coco. I’m just handing over to Priya for day shift, is that okay?
[PATIENT]: Sure.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Hi, Coco. I’m Priya. We’ll do a quick bedside handover.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Great. This is bed three, Coco Constantino, 61 years old, under Dr. Hudgens. He came in with pneumonia and an allergic reaction to penicillin.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Coco, can you confirm your name for me?
[PATIENT]: Coco Constantino.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thank you. Any allergies?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Yes—penicillin. He was accidentally prescribed penicillin for the pneumonia and developed a rash, fever, and difficulty breathing afterward. Allergy is now documented.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Noted—penicillin allergy with rash, fever, breathing difficulty.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Respiratory-wise, he’s on his regular puffers with PRN nebulisers. He’s also on prednisolone; we’re doing random BGLs. He’s on oral antibiotics and an antihistamine.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: I will do  BGL checks, and give oral ABs (non-penicillin), and antihistamine as ordered.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Today he’s afebrile. He’s on oxygen at 2 litres via nasal prongs. Sats are normal and all other obs are stable. He has a QADDS of 2 for breathing the doctors are aware.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Coco, how’s your breathing now?
[PATIENT]: Better than yesterday.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Good to hear. Any itch or rash still bothering you?
[PATIENT]: A bit of itch, but it’s settling.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He’s self-caring and ambulant.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: The plan for today is to continue oxygen at 2 L and wean as tolerated, monitor sats and obs, continue puffers/PRN nebs, steroids with random BGLs, oral antibiotics and antihistamine. We’ll reinforce the penicillin allergy bracelet and chart.
[PATIENT]: Okay.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Okay are you happy with the handover
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks. Coco, press the call bell if you feel short of breath or the rash worsens. I’ll be back to check your sugars and see if we can reduce the oxygen later.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Neil came in with severe allergy symptoms and a history of asthma. He had difficulty breathing and was very chesty on arrival. He was febrile with a temperature of 38.8.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: We took blood cultures and gave paracetamol with good effect. The medical team has reviewed; Dr Tim was informed, and antibiotics have been changed as per their plan.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: So the Blood cultures are still pending?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Yes.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: How’s your breathing now, Neil?
[PATIENT]: Better than before, still a bit tight but improving.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay, we’ll keep a close eye on that.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He’s on a general diet, self-caring, and ambulant.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Any other concerns overnight?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: No acute events after paracetamol. He’s been comfortable and mobilizing independently.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Great. Any specific precautions?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Just routine observations, we are monitoring his temperature and respiratory status, and giving the antibiotics as charted.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Neil, we’ll keep checking your observations and let you know when any results come back. Please use the call bell if your breathing worsens or you feel unwell.
[PATIENT]: Will do, thanks.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks for the handover.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: No worries. I’m off—call me if you need anything before I go.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: In bed 7 we have Linda Donald, 83 years old, under Dr Harrod.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Hi Linda, I’m the incoming nurse my name is Brett. We’ll just do a quick bedside handover together, is that okay?
[PATIENT]: Okay.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Linda came in for investigation due to memory problems and increasing confusion.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Have her observations been checked?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Yes, obs are done and all stable, nothing remarkable.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Has the medical team seen her yet?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Not yet.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: How is she getting around?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She’s ambulant with a wheely walker, with 1 to standby assist.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: We’ll make sure it’s within reach and help you as needed, don't get up on your own
[PATIENT]: Thank you.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Any diet orders?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She's on a soft diet which she is tolerating well, but needs help with setting up the tray table, and taking the lids off the cups. 
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay is there anything else that I need to know?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: No, shes stable.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: So, the plan is to continue regular observations, assist with mobility using the walker, help her with her meals and wait for the team to review her.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: I think I have covered everything.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Linda, do you need anything before we go?
[PATIENT]: No, I’m fine.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: We’ll be back shortly. Please use the call bell if you need help.

example.text:
[NURSE]: Hi, thanks for coming. I wanted to hand over Mrs. Joan Wallace, 69 years old, currently Day 5 post-abdominal surgery for bowel obstruction. She’s still nil by mouth, and the surgical team has recommended a PEG insertion for long-term nutrition support.
[DIETITIAN]: Thanks. Has she been receiving any nutrition support so far?
[NURSE]: Yes, she’s been on IV fluids only. No TPN was started due to concerns about central access and infection risk. She’s starting to show signs of nutritional depletion—fatigue, muscle wasting, and low energy.
[DIETITIAN]: Has the PEG been scheduled?
[NURSE]: Not yet. Gastroenterology has been consulted and will assess her today. Once inserted, she’ll need a feeding plan—likely starting with low-volume, isotonic formula, then gradually increasing.
[DIETITIAN]: Any relevant medical history?
[NURSE]: Yes she has Type 2 diabetes, Hypertension, History of diverticulitis and
No known drug allergies.
[DIETITIAN]: How is she tolerating nil by mouth?
[NURSE]: She’s coping but frustrated. She’s alert and understands the need for PEG feeding. I’ve explained the basics, but she’d benefit from a more detailed discussion with you.
[DIETITIAN]: Hi Mrs. Wallace, I’m the dietitian. I’ll be helping with your nutrition once the feeding tube is in place. We’ll start slowly and make sure you’re comfortable.
[PATIENT]: Thank you. I just want to feel stronger again.
[DIETITIAN]: We’ll work on that together.
[NURSE]: She’s due for bloods tomorrow—please check electrolytes, glucose, and nutritional markers. Let me know if you need anything else.
[DIETITIAN]: Will do. I’ll draft a feeding plan and follow up after the PEG is inserted.

example.text:
[NURSE]: Hi Dr. Patel, thanks for coming. I’d like you to review Ms. Evelyn Grant in bed 9. She’s a 68-year-old admitted with a urinary tract infection, now deteriorating—likely urosepsis.
[DOCTOR]: What’s happening?
[NURSE]: Over the past few hours, she’s become increasingly tachycardic and febrile. Her Q-ADDS score is 6, which triggered escalation. She’s also more confused than her baseline—normally oriented but now disoriented to time and place.
[DOCTOR]: Can you give me her latest observations?
[NURSE]: BP: 98/62, HR: 112 bpm, RR: 22, Temp: 38.6°C, SpO?: 95% on room air, Conscious state: Alert but confused, Q-ADDS score: 6 (HR + Temp + RR + confusion)
[DOCTOR]: Has she had any recent bloods or cultures?
[NURSE]: Yes. Bloods were taken this morning: WCC: 14.2, CRP: 98, Creatinine: 102 (baseline ~85) Urine sample: Sent, we are waiting results Lactate: Not yet done—would you like it ordered?
[DOCTOR]: Any IV access?
[NURSE]: No current vascular access. She had a cannula yesterday, but it was removed due to tissuing. I can insert a new one now.
[DOCTOR]: What’s her fluid balance?
[NURSE]: Input (last 24h): ~1200 mL (oral + IV), Output: ~600 mL urine, no vomiting or diarrhoea, Net balance: +600 mL, Urine output: Reduced over last 6 hours—only 100 mL
[DOCTOR]: Allergy status?
[NURSE]: Documented penicillin allergy—rash and swelling previously.
[DOCTOR]: Current medications?
[NURSE]: Paracetamol 1g QID, IV fluids: Normal saline at 100 mL/hr, No antibiotics yet—awaiting review due to allergy
[DOCTOR]: Okay. I’ll assess her now. Let’s insert a cannula, take a lactate, and start IV ceftriaxone and gentamicin. We’ll monitor closely and consider AMU transfer if she worsens.
[NURSE]: I’ll insert the cannula, draw the lactate, and prep the antibiotics. I’ll also notify AMU if her Q-ADDS increases or confusion worsens.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: We will wait for a time for the stent and the ultrasound on Friday.

[PATIENT]: Sure.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Thanks, Edwin. So, room 1 bed 3, this is Edwin Palma, 54, under Dr. Willow. Can I just confirm your identity?
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks, Edwin.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He has prostate cancer so He has come in for an assessment. He’s had a CT abdomen and an x-ray; both results are still pending.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: When were they done.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: 1000 am this morning. The plan is that he will be discharged if results are negative; otherwise he’ll be treated as an outpatient. We’re still awaiting the team’s review and the go-ahead. Otherwise, he’s stable.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks. I’ll keep an eye out for the results and page the team for review once they’re available.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Edwin, how are you feeling right now—any pain or new concerns?
[PATIENT]: I’m okay. No new issues.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Great. There are no immediate nursing issues to flag. His Vitals and status stable.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: All right. Edwin, once the doctors review your scans, we’ll let you know the outcome and next steps. If you’re cleared, we’ll arrange your discharge; if not, we’ll organise the outpatient plan.
[PATIENT]: Sounds good. Thank you.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Do you need anything before we go?
[PATIENT]: I’m fine, thanks.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Perfect. I’ll hand over the pager to you. Thanks, Edwin.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks. I’ll be back shortly to update you when we hear from the team.

example.text:
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Good Morning. I’ll take over from here—shall we do bedside handover for Bed 3?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Sure. Hi Evan, this is Mia, she’ll be looking after you today.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Hi Evan. Can you tell me your name and age?
[PATIENT]: Evan Stephenson, 22.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks, Evan. We’ll chat while we check a few things.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: So, Bed 3: Evan Stephenson, 22 years old. He came in after a fall and has rhabdomyolysis with acute kidney failure. He had very low blood pressure in ED and received a Gelofusine infusion stat. He’s more stable now, which is why he’s been transferred to the ward.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He’s got an IDC in situ, and for strict fluid balance charting. IV fluids are running at 803 mL per hour as charted.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Just confirming—eight-zero-three per hour? I’ll double-check the order and the pump after handover.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Yes, that’s correct per the current order.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He’s on lying and standing blood pressures, daily weights, and daily bloods.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He appears swollen and bruised on the left side of his body. He’s for a review regarding his mobility. At the moment he’s resting in bed and currently stable.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Evan, any pain right now, or dizziness?
[PATIENT]: Bit sore on the left side, but I’m okay lying still.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks. I’ll get your pain score shortly and make sure you’re comfortable.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Urine output’s being tracked on the fluid balance?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Yes—IDC is patent and draining, the FBC is up to date.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Great. I’ll check your IV fluids, review the orthostatic BP plan, and keep up with the daily weights and bloods. I’ll also follow up on the mobility review.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Perfect. That’s everything from me.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Evan, is there anything you need right now before I check your pumps and observations?
[PATIENT]: Some water if I’m allowed?
[INCOMING_NURSE]: I’ll confirm your fluid orders and be right back. Use your call bell if you need anything.

example.text:
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Hi, I’m handing over Mr. Robert Hughes, 72 years old, currently admitted under a Treatment Authority. Diagnosis is late-onset schizophrenia, admitted with persecutory delusions.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: What’s his presentation today?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He remains suspicious and is refusing meals, stating that his food is poisoned. He has refused his morning risperidone 0.5 mg and is declining all blood tests. He’s also refusing routine obs.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Any signs of delirium?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Yes — 4AT score is 6. He appears intermittently disoriented and his mental state is fluctuating. Doctors have requested delirium care strategies — regular reorientation, low-stimulus environment, clear explanations. Food and fluid charts commenced.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: What’s his legal and social situation?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He’s under guardianship through the Office of the Public Guardian. No local family or supports.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: And the current risk and plan?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He’s refusing oral meds, so the team is considering alternative routes if refusal persists. Needs close supervision for nutrition, hydration, and risk of further deterioration. Maintain reorientation and escalate if agitation or aggression increases.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks. I’ll continue with the delirium care approach and monitor intake and risk.

example.text:
[Hospital Nurse]: Hi, I’m handing over Mrs. Emily Carter, a 38-year-old patient who was admitted three days ago and has now been newly diagnosed with bipolar disorder following a manic episode. She’s being discharged today and will require follow-up in the community.
[Community Nurse]: Thanks. Can you tell me a bit about her presentation?
[Hospital Nurse]: She was admitted after displaying elevated mood, pressured speech, and impulsive behaviour. No psychotic features noted. She’s now stabilised on medication and insight is improving. She’s aware of her diagnosis and has been engaging well with the mental health team.
[Community Nurse]: What’s her current medication regimen?
[Hospital Nurse]: She’s been started on: Lithium carbonate 400 mg BD – levels to be monitored, Quetiapine 300 mg nocte, PRN lorazepam 1 mg for agitation – not required in the last 48 hours there are No known drug allergies.
[Community Nurse]: Any physical health concerns?
[Hospital Nurse]: Vitals are stable. She’s independent with ADLs. No pressure areas noted. She’s been eating and drinking well, and her fluid balance is normal. Bowels have been regular.
[Community Nurse]: What’s her home situation?
[Hospital Nurse]: She lives with her husband and three children aged 4, 7, and 12, plus a dog. Her husband has been very supportive and is aware of the diagnosis. He’s keen to be involved in her care and has asked for education around mood monitoring and medication.
[Community Nurse]: Any follow-up arranged?
[Hospital Nurse]: Yes, she’s been referred to the community mental health team for ongoing support, including mood tracking, medication adherence, and psychoeducation. She’ll also need a home visit within 48 hours to assess safety and support needs.
[Community Nurse]: Thanks. I’ll follow up with the family and ensure she’s linked in with the right services.
[Hospital Nurse]: Great. Let me know if you need anything further from the inpatient team.

example.text:
[Outgoing Nurse]: Hi, I’m handing over Mrs. Joan Ellis in bed 2. She’s an 81-year-old patient admitted with a urinary tract infection and worsening confusion. She’s currently alert but disoriented and has been incontinent of both urine and bowels during the shift.
[Incoming Nurse]: Thanks. What’s her current Q-ADDS score?
[Outgoing Nurse]: Her Q-ADDS score is 5—based on confusion, elevated temperature, and increased respiratory rate. Latest observations are BP: 132/78, HR: 94 bpm, RR: 22, Temp: 38.3°C, SpO?: 96% on room air, she is Alert but confused.
[Incoming Nurse]: Is she on any monitoring charts?
[Outgoing Nurse]: Yes, a Fluid Balance Chart – she’s had ~900 mL oral intake today, and incontinent of urine twice. A Bowel Chart – opened bowels once this morning, loose stool and a Falls Risk Chart – high risk due to confusion and mobility issues.
[Incoming Nurse]: Any pressure area concerns?
[Outgoing Nurse]: No current injuries, but she’s at risk. She’s on a pressure-relieving mattress and being repositioned every 2 hours. Skin checks are ongoing—no redness noted.
[Incoming Nurse]: What about hygiene?
[Outgoing Nurse]: She’s had a full wash this morning, including peri-care. She’ll likely need another wash later due to incontinence. Continence aids are in use.
[Incoming Nurse]: Any IV access or medications?
[Outgoing Nurse]: No IV access currently. She’s on: Paracetamol 1g QID, IV Ceftriaxone 1g daily – given this morning, PRN lorazepam 0.5 mg – not required today
No known allergies.
[Incoming Nurse]: Thanks. I’ll continue monitoring, update the charts, and assist with hygiene as needed.

example.text:
[Hospital Nurse]: Hi, I’m handing over Mr. Harold Bennett, a 79-year-old resident from Greenview Aged Care Facility. He was admitted 5 days ago with a chest infection and is now medically stable and ready for discharge back to the nursing home.
[Nursing Home Nurse]: Thanks. What’s his current condition?
[Hospital Nurse]: He’s alert and orientated, though mildly fatigued. He’s completed a course of IV antibiotics—ceftriaxone—and has now transitioned to oral amoxicillin 500 mg TDS, which he’ll continue for another 3 days. His SpO? is 96% on room air, and he’s no longer requiring supplemental oxygen.
[Nursing Home Nurse]: Any ongoing care needs?
[Hospital Nurse]: Yes:  he needs Pressure area care: He’s at moderate risk (Waterlow score 16), so continue 2-hourly repositioning and maintain use of a pressure-relieving mattress. His Fluid balance chart shows he’s been drinking well, no IV fluids required. Input ~1600 mL/day, output ~1400 mL/day. The Bowel chart:  shows his Last bowel movement was yesterday—formed stool. Continue monitoring. He’s Mobilising with assistance. Physiotherapy has recommended gentle walking with a frame. His Q-ADDS score: Currently 2 (mild fatigue and recent infection). Continue routine obs twice daily unless deterioration.
[Nursing Home Nurse]: Any medications or allergies?
[Hospital Nurse]: He’s on: Amoxicillin 500 mg TDS (3 days remaining), Paracetamol 1g QID PRN, Atorvastatin 20 mg nocte, he has No known drug allergies.
[Nursing Home Nurse]: Thanks. I’ll continue monitoring and update the GP if needed.
[Hospital Nurse]: Perfect. Discharge summary and medication chart are with the transfer paperwork. Let me know if you need anything further.

example.text:
[NURSE]: Hi Dr. Nguyen, I need you to review Ms. Lara Bennett in bed 5. She’s a 56-year-old patient with a known history of epilepsy. She had a tonic-clonic seizure about 20 minutes ago on the ward. It lasted approximately 90 seconds and she’s now post-ictal—drowsy but rousable.
[DOCTOR]: Thanks. Is she stable now?
[NURSE]:Yes, she’s breathing spontaneously and maintaining her airway. No signs of trauma or tongue injury. She’s currently on 4-hourly neuro obs. Her latest vitals are:BP: 138/84, HR: 92 bpm, RR: 16, Temp: 36.9°C, SpO?: 98% on room air, GCS: 13,Q-ADDS score: 4 (GCS + seizure)
[DOCTOR]: Any IV access?
[NURSE]: Yes, she has a patent IV cannula in her left forearm. No IV fluids running currently—she’s tolerating oral intake. No signs of dehydration.
[DOCTOR]: Any allergies?
[NURSE]: Yes, she has a documented allergy to phenytoin—rash and dizziness previously.
[DOCTOR]: Is she catheterised?
[NURSE]: Yes, she has an indwelling catheter (IDC) in place for monitoring. Output has been normal—clear urine, ~300 mL over the last 4 hours.
[DOCTOR]: Any recent bloods?
[NURSE]: Yes, FBC and electrolytes were taken this morning: Hb: 128, WCC: 7.4, Platelets: 240, Na: 136, K: 4.2, Creatinine: 76, No major abnormalities.
[DOCTOR]: Has the family been informed?
[NURSE]: Yes, I’ve spoken to her daughter. She’s on her way in and aware of the situation. I’ve reassured her that Lara is stable but still recovering.
[DOCTOR]: Thanks. Let’s continue neuro obs, monitor for any further seizures, and review her antiepileptic regimen. If she has another seizure or her GCS drops, please escalate immediately.
[NURSE]: I’ll keep monitoring and update you if anything changes.

example.text:
[ED NURSE]: Hi, I’m handing over Maria Santos, 58 years old, coming up to the ward with cellulitis on her left lower leg. She’s been started on IV antibiotics and is stable for transfer.
[WARD NURSE]: Thanks. What’s her current status?
[ED NURSE]: Vitals are stable — temp 37.6°C, HR 84, BP 122/78, RR 18, SpO? 98% on room air. The affected leg is red, warm, and swollen from mid-calf to ankle. No signs of abscess or necrosis.
[WARD NURSE]: Okay. What’s the antibiotic plan?
[ED NURSE]: She’s on IV cefazolin, 1g every 8 hours. First dose was given in ED about an hour ago. Next dose is due at 10 PM. No known drug allergies.
[WARD NURSE]: Got it. Any IV access?
[ED NURSE]: Yes, 20G cannula in the right forearm — site is clean, dry, and patent. Charted for daily review. She’s also had IV fluids earlier, but now tolerating oral intake.
[WARD NURSE]: Any pain management?
[ED NURSE]: She’s had paracetamol 1g orally — pain is currently 4/10. PRN analgesia is charted.
[WARD NURSE]: Any behavioural or cognitive concerns?
[ED NURSE]: No concerns. She’s alert, oriented, and understands the treatment plan. Mobilising with assistance due to leg discomfort.
[WARD NURSE]: Thanks. I’ll check the IV site and meds when she arrives. Let me know if anything changes before transfer.

example.text:
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Good morning, Mr. Patel. I’m Jack, and I’ll be your nurse for today. We’ll do a quick bedside handover with my colleague, if that’s okay.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Hi, Mr. Patel. This is the nurse taking over for the day. Could you please confirm your full name?
[PATIENT]: Rakesh Patel.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Thank you. This is Mr. Rakesh Patel in Bed 1, Room 3, aged 58, under Dr. Morrison, General Surgeon.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Mr. Patel was admitted this morning for an elective inguinal hernia repair. He’s nil by mouth and awaiting theatre. Pre-op bloods, ECG, and consent have been completed. He’s aware of the procedure and has no concerns at this stage.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He’s hemodynamically stable. No pain reported currently. He’s had mild discomfort over the past few weeks, especially with lifting. No signs of strangulation or obstruction. Vitals are within normal limits.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Mr. Patel, how are you feeling this morning? Any pain or nausea?
[PATIENT]: No pain right now, just a bit nervous.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Understandable. He’s been reassured and is coping well. No allergies. Medications include atorvastatin 20mg daily and paracetamol PRN. No anticoagulants. No previous surgeries.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: I’ll follow up with the surgical team and theatre staff. Is there anything you need before we finish handover?
[PATIENT]: No, I’m okay. Thanks.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Please use the call bell if you need anything. I’ll leave you in good hands.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: I’ll be back shortly to check your observations and review your chart, Mr. Patel.

example.text:
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Good morning, Mr. Jackson. I’m Sarah, and I’ll be your nurse for today. We’ll do a quick bedside handover with my colleague, if that’s okay.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Hi, Mr. Jackson. This is the nurse taking over for the day. Could you please confirm your full name?
[PATIENT]: David Jackson.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Thank you. This is Mr. David Jackson in Bed 4, Room 6, aged 64, under Dr. Patel, Orthopaedic Consultant.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Mr. Jackson is awaiting ORIF surgery for a left femoral neck fracture, scheduled for tomorrow. He’s been stable overnight, but this morning he reported lower abdominal discomfort and has not passed urine since yesterday evening.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Bladder scan showed retention of 650 mL. Medical team reviewed and requested an IDC insertion. He’s alert, cooperative, and understands the procedure. No known allergies. Pain is currently 3/10 on movement.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Mr. Jackson, I’ll be inserting a catheter shortly to help relieve the pressure in your bladder. I’ll explain everything before we begin.
[PATIENT]: Okay, thank you. It’s really uncomfortable.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: I understand. I’ll get everything ready now.
[SARAH]: Hey, Jess—sorry to interrupt. I’ve got a patient in Room 6 with urinary retention and needs an IDC. I haven’t done one before—would you mind assisting or supervising?
[JESS]: Of course, happy to help. Let’s grab the trolley and go through it together. I’ll walk you through the steps.
[SARAH]: Thanks so much. I’ve read the protocol, just haven’t had the chance to do one hands-on yet.
[JESS]: No worries—we’ll take it slow and make sure Mr. Jackson is comfortable throughout.
[NURSE SARAH]: Hi Mr. Jackson, I just wanted to check in. I understand you’re still feeling quite uncomfortable.
[PATIENT]: Yes, I still haven’t been able to pass urine. It’s getting worse.
[NURSE SARAH]: I’m sorry to hear that. We’ve done a bladder scan and it shows you’re retaining quite a bit—over 700 mL. The doctor will be coming shortly to insert a catheter to relieve the pressure.
[PATIENT]: Okay, thank you.
[NURSE SARAH]: Hi Dr. Patel, sorry to interrupt. Mr. Jackson in Room 6 has urinary retention—bladder scan shows 740 mL. I attempted an IDC but met resistance and he was quite uncomfortable. Would you be able to insert it?
[DR. PATEL]: Yes, I can do that. Can you get the trolley set up and let me know when it’s ready?
[NURSE SARAH]: Absolutely. I’ll prepare the sterile field now.
[NURSE SARAH]: Dr. Patel, the trolley is set up and Mr. Jackson has been informed. He’s ready when you are.
[DR. PATEL]: Great, let’s go ahead. Can you assist with maintaining the sterile field?
[NURSE SARAH]: Of course.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Hi, I'm handing over bed 11, Mr. Thomas Nguyen, 64 years old. He’s been admitted with multiple left-sided rib fractures—ribs 5 through 8—after a fall from a ladder yesterday.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Ouch. How’s he doing now?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He’s stable but in quite a bit of pain, especially with deep breathing and movement. He’s on regular paracetamol and oxycodone PRN. We’ve also started a fentanyl PCA overnight, which he’s using appropriately.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Any respiratory concerns?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: No signs of pneumothorax or haemothorax on imaging. Chest X-ray shows isolated rib fractures. He’s on 2 L nasal prongs to maintain sats above 94%. We’re encouraging deep breathing and coughing—he’s using the incentive spirometer.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Any comorbidities?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Hypertension and mild COPD. No known allergies. He’s a non-smoker now but has a 30-pack-year history.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Mobilising?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: With assistance. Physio reviewed this morning and will continue daily. He’s slow but safe with a frame. Needs supervision for toileting.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Any communication or support needs?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: English is his first language. Lives with his wife. He’s a bit frustrated with the pain but very cooperative.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Got it. I’ll keep an eye on his pain and respiratory effort.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Perfect. Let me know if his pain escalates or if there are any signs of respiratory compromise. All documentation is up to date, including pain scores and PCA charting.

preds.quote: He’s been admitted with multiple left-sided rib fractures—ribs 5 through 8—after a fall from a ladder yesterday.

preds.label: BACKGROUND
preds.quote: Hypertension and mild COPD. No known allergies. He’s a non-smoker now but has a 30-pack-year history.

preds.label: BACKGROUND
preds.quote: English is his first language.

preds.label: BACKGROUND
preds.quote: Lives with his wife.

preds.label: ASSESSMENT
preds.quote: He's stable but in quite a bit of pain, especially with deep breathing and movement.

preds.label: ASSESSMENT
preds.quote: No signs of pneumothorax or haemothorax on imaging.

preds.label: ASSESSMENT
preds.quote: Chest X-ray shows isolated rib fractures.

preds.label: ASSESSMENT
preds.quote: He’s on 2 L nasal prongs to maintain sats above 94%.

preds.label: ASSESSMENT
preds.quote: We’re encouraging deep breathing and coughing—he’s using the incentive spirometer.

preds.label: ASSESSMENT
preds.quote: He’s on regular paracetamol and oxycodone PRN.

preds.label: ASSESSMENT
preds.quote: We’ve also started a fentanyl PCA overnight, which he’s using appropriately.

preds.label: ASSESSMENT
preds.quote: He’s a bit frustrated with the pain but very cooperative.

preds.label: RECOMMENDATION
preds.quote: Physio reviewed this morning and will continue daily.

preds.label: RECOMMENDATION
preds.quote: Needs supervision for toileting.

preds.label: RECOMMENDATION
preds.quote: Let me know if his pain escalates or if there are any signs of respiratory compromise.

example.text:
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Hi, I'm John, handing over bed 2, Ms. Leila Haddad, 59 years old. She’s been admitted with a large pericardial effusion—likely secondary to metastatic breast cancer. She’s for pericardiocentesis this afternoon.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay. How is she currently?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She’s haemodynamically stable but symptomatic—short of breath at rest, mild chest tightness, and fatigue. No syncope or hypotension. She’s on 2 L nasal prongs to maintain sats around 94%.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: What’s been done so far?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She’s had an urgent echo showing a large effusion with early signs of tamponade. Cardiology has reviewed and booked her for ultrasound-guided pericardiocentesis this afternoon. Consent is done.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: IV access?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Two good IVs—one 18G in the left AC and a 20G in the right forearm. Both patent. She’s on maintenance IV fluids—normal saline at 75 mL/hr.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Medications?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She’s had IV dexamethasone 8 mg this morning and regular paracetamol for discomfort. PRN midazolam is charted for the procedure. No anticoagulants on board. NKDA.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Observations?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: BP 102/68, HR 98, RR 22, SpO? 94% on 2 L, Temp 36.8. She’s alert and oriented but anxious. ECG shows low voltage QRS, no arrhythmias.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Any support needs?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: English is her second language—Arabic is her first. She understands most things but prefers slow explanations. Her daughter is bilingual and has been helping. Interpreter has been requested for post-procedure education.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Got it. I’ll keep monitoring her obs closely and prep her for the drain.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Perfect. Let me know if she deteriorates—especially signs of tamponade like hypotension or muffled heart sounds. All documentation is up to date, including consent, obs, and fluid balance.

example.text:
[ED NURSE]: Hi, I’m handing over Mrs. Anna Lewis, 35 years old, being transferred to the surgical ward. Anna, this is Nurse Claire, who’ll be looking after you now. Mark, you’re welcome to stay with her as long as you need.
[WARD NURSE]: Hi Anna, hi Mark. I’m really sorry you’re going through this. I’ll do everything I can to make you comfortable and supported.
[PATIENT]: Thank you. I’m still trying to process everything.
[ED NURSE]: Anna presented to ED overnight with vaginal bleeding and cramping at 10 weeks gestation. An ultrasound confirmed no fetal heartbeat. She’s been reviewed by O&G and is for a D&C later today.
[WARD NURSE]: I’m so sorry, Anna. We’ll make sure you’re cared for gently. Have you had anything to eat or drink?
[PATIENT]: No, I haven’t eaten since yesterday evening.
[ED NURSE]: She’s been kept Nil by mouth since 2:00 AM. Vitals are stable—BP 110/70, HR 84, afebrile. She’s had paracetamol and a single dose of IV fluids. No allergies. She has a 20G IV in the left forearm, patent and flushed.
[WARD NURSE]: Any medications charted?
[ED NURSE]: Just analgesia and PRNs. No antibiotics yet. She’s on a fluid balance chart, and we’ve started Q-ADDS—currently scoring 1. She’s understandably tearful but oriented and engaging.
[DOCTOR]: (enters) Anna, I’m Dr. Nguyen from the surgical team. I’m very sorry for your loss. We’ll be performing a D&C this afternoon to help manage the bleeding and support your recovery. We’ll talk you through everything and answer any questions.
[PATIENT]: Will I be asleep for it?
[DOCTOR]: Yes, you’ll be under a light general anaesthetic. It’s a short procedure, and we’ll monitor you closely afterward.
[HUSBAND]: Can I stay with her until she goes to theatre?
[WARD NURSE]: Absolutely. We’ll make sure you’re both supported. I’ll also check in with the social worker and pastoral care team if you’d like someone to talk to.
[ED NURSE]: All documentation is up to date—fluid chart, Q-ADDS, and consent form. Please let the team know if her bleeding increases or if she becomes more distressed.

example.text:
[WARD NURSE]: Hi, I’m handing over Mrs. Evelyn Grant, 87 years old, being transferred to the transit lounge to await transport back to her nursing home. Evelyn, this is Nurse Tom, who’ll be looking after you until your transport arrives.
[TRANSIT LOUNGE NURSE]: Hi Evelyn, lovely to meet you. We’ll make sure you’re comfortable while you wait.
[WARD NURSE]: Evelyn was admitted five days ago with aspiration pneumonia. She’s responded well to IV antibiotics and supportive care. She’s now afebrile, respiratory rate is 18, SpO? 96% on room air, and she’s mobilising short distances with assistance.
[TRANSIT LOUNGE NURSE]: Great. Any swallowing concerns?
[WARD NURSE]: Yes, she has known dysphagia—thickened fluids and minced moist diet. She’s been reviewed by speech pathology and is safe to resume her usual nursing home diet plan. No signs of aspiration since admission.
[TRANSIT LOUNGE NURSE]: Okay. Any medications due?
[WARD NURSE]: No meds due during transit. She’s had her morning meds—oral antibiotics completed yesterday. No allergies. She has a 22G IV in the left hand, but it can be removed before discharge.
[TRANSIT LOUNGE NURSE]: Any behavioural concerns?
[WARD NURSE]: No. She’s pleasant, a bit confused at times but reorients easily. Nursing home staff are aware and familiar with her baseline.
[TRANSIT LOUNGE NURSE]: Got it. Is transport booked?
[WARD NURSE]: Yes, booked for 11:30 AM. All discharge paperwork is complete, including medication summary and nursing home handover form. Please let the team know if there’s any delay or change in her condition.

example.text:
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Good Morning, Rebecca. I’m Mia, I’ll be looking after you today. I’m just going to get handover from Alex, is that okay?
[PATIENT]: Sure.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Hi, Mia. This is Rebecca Burks who is a 54 year old, under Dr Dalianis.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Hi Rebecca. Can you please tell me your full name and date of birth?
[PATIENT]: Rebecca Burks, and it’s the 14th of May, 1970.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thank you. Any allergies we need to know about?
[PATIENT]: None that I’m aware of.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Presentation was dizziness, weakness, tachycardia and nausea. She’s diagnosed with ischaemic heart disease, with a history of atherosclerosis and breast cancer.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: How are you feeling right now, Rebecca?
[PATIENT]: Still a bit weak and a little queasy, but better than yesterday.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She’s otherwise stable today. The patient is self-caring and ambulant, but she needs a little supervision when walking—so one assist because of the weakness.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: We’ll make sure someone walks with you.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She’s on regular anti-emetics before meals for her nausea, and she’s also got regular pain relief charted.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: I’ll check when the next anti-emetic is due before breakfast.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Observations are visible on the station screens, but they still need to be written into the obs chart each round.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: We need to do a ECG printout at the start of each shift, and any time there’s an abnormality. we put the printouts in her chart.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Rebecca I’ll do a baseline ECG after handover so we have it for this shift.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: The blood pressure needs to be done on her right arm due to her right-sided mastectomy.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks for the reminder. I’ll use the left arm only and pop a “no BP right arm” sign if it’s not already up.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Doctors are around frequently, so we can check anything with them as needed.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Rebecca, we’ll help you up with one person and keep your call bell close. Anything you need before we go?
[PATIENT]: Could I have some water, please?
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Of course—I’ll bring that in with your meds. Plan for the shift: baseline ECG and file, regular obs documented in the chart, anti-emetic before meals, pain relief as needed, supervise mobilising with one assist, and BP on the left arm only.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: That’s everything from me.
[PATIENT]: Thank you both.

pred_spans.quote: Still a bit weak and a little queasy, but better than yesterday.

pred_spans.label: ASSESSMENT

example.text:
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Good Morning. Bed 4 is Robert Lewis, but he prefers Bob.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Hi Bob, I’m taking over your care now. Is it okay if we do handover at the bedside?
[PATIENT]: Sure.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks, Bob.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Bob is 62, under Dr. Johnson. He came in with a heart attack and has had a CABG.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Any other medical history?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Notes say “high HD.” We’ll need to clarify whether that’s hypertension or hyperlipidaemia in the chart/with the team.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay, I’ll confirm that in the notes.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He’s due for MRSA and VRE surveillance swabs.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: I’ll collect those this morning.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Ongoing surgical wound care—site looks clean and is healing well.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Bob, we’ll take a quick look later when we do your checks. Any pain at the wound site?
[PATIENT]: It’s okay, it's just a bit tender.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He’s been complaining of constipation— there has been no bowel movement for three days. Regular aperients have been given with good effect; he reports some relief.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay, Bob, we’ll keep up the aperients and monitor for a bowel motion. Let us know if you feel any abdominal pain or nausea.
[PATIENT]: Will do.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: All observations are stable.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Great. Any lines or drains?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: No additional lines to note. Just routine post-op wound care.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks. Plan for today: collect MRSA/VRE swabs, continue surgical wound care, manage constipation, and routine obs. Anything else pending with Dr. Johnson?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: There are no other outstanding tasks from my end.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Bob, is there anything you need right now?
[PATIENT]: I’m okay, thanks.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Alright, I’ll be back shortly to do your checks and get those swabs done.

example.text:
[Outgoing Nurse]: Hi, I’m handing over Mrs. Elaine Morris in bed 6. She’s an 84-year-old patient with reduced mobility following a recent pneumonia admission. She has a stage 2 pressure injury on her right hip.
[Incoming Nurse]: Thanks. What’s the current condition of the wound?
[Outgoing Nurse]: It’s a shallow ulcer with partial thickness skin loss. The wound bed is moist but clean, with no signs of infection. There’s mild erythema around the edges. The wound care nurse reviewed it this morning and recommended continuing with Allevyn Gentle Border dressing.
[Incoming Nurse]: How often does it need changing?
[Outgoing Nurse]: Every 3 days unless soiled or lifting. The next dressing change is due on Friday. We’re documenting progress in the wound chart and taking weekly photos for review.
[Incoming Nurse]: What’s her Waterlow score?
[Outgoing Nurse]: Waterlow score is 18, so she’s at high risk. She’s on a pressure-relieving mattress and we’re repositioning her every 2 hours.
[Incoming Nurse]: Any other relevant care?
[Outgoing Nurse]: Yes:  she has No IV access currently, her Oral intake is adequate, there’s No IDC, but she is continent of urine and bowels, Pain score is 1/10 at rest, no analgesia required, Skin integrity checks are ongoing, no other areas of concern
[Incoming Nurse]: Thanks. I’ll continue the pressure care, monitor the wound, and follow the dressing schedule.

example.text:
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Good Morning, Lawrence. I’m Evie, taking over your care. I’ll just get a quick bedside handover from Jack, if that’s okay.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Hi, Evie. This is Bed 8, Lawrence Wong, who is 56 years old, under Dr Lee. He came in with a severe headache. He’s on regular analgesia and his observations have been stable. QADDS of zero. 
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Could you please confirm your full name and date of birth?
[PATIENT]: Lawrence Wong, and 25 December 1968.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thank you. Any allergies to medications?
[PATIENT]: No, none that I know of.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Overnight he reported a headache so  I gave him some Endone as charted, with good effect, there are no other issues noted.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Lawrence, how’s your head feeling now—any pain, nausea, or light sensitivity?
[PATIENT]: It’s okay at the moment—no nausea or light sensitivity.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: we will give you regular analgesia as charted.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Yes the Panadol is due at 1330. His Obs remain stable.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Perfect. So the plans is we’ll continue regular analgesia, monitor your pain and observations, and let Dr Lee’s team know if anything changes. Lawrence, please buzz if the headache returns or gets worse.
[PATIENT]: Will do. Thank you.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Anything else before Jack heads off?
[PATIENT]: I’m fine, thanks.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: All right, I’m off. Thanks, Lawrence.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks, Jack. I’ll be back shortly, Lawrence.

example.text:
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Good Morning, Phil. I’m Alex, I’ll be looking after you today. I’m just going to get handover from Sam, is that okay?
[PATIENT]: Sure, that’s fine.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Thanks, Phil. So, this is Phil Albert Rivet, He's 64 years old, In bed 2, under Dr. Garcia.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Hi Phil, can you confirm your full name for me, and I’ll check your wristband?
[PATIENT]: Phil Albert Rivet.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thank you.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Phil came in by ambulance four days ago for thrombolytic therapy. He’s got a long history of cardiac problems of about 14 years.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He was on regular GTN on arrival and he’s still on regular GTN as charted.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay, so continuing nitrates as per the med chart.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: The obs are stable, and he’s gradually improving. There have been no other problems noted overnight.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Are there any changes in your symptoms, Phil? Any chest pain or shortness of breath right now?
[PATIENT]: No, I’m comfortable at the moment.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Good to hear. I’ll keep an eye on your vitals and meds.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: That’s pretty much it from me. He's Stable,and improving, we are continuing with the GTN, and routine obs.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks. I’ll review the chart and do your next set of obs shortly. Phil, buzz if you need anything.
[PATIENT]: Will do, thanks.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Thanks, Phil. I’ll head off. Alex, he’s all yours.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks, Sam.
