example.text:
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Good Morning, Hildy. I'm just here with my colleague to do bedside handover, is that okay?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Hi there. This is Hildy Hutter in room 4, bed 6, under Dr. Forbes.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Hildy, could you tell us your full name and date of birth?
[PATIENT]: Oh… I’m waiting for the bus, dear.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: That’s alright, Hildy. We’ll just check your ID band and IV medications.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Hildy is a lovely 91-year-old lady admitted with a urinary tract infection.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She’s currently on IV antibiotics. The doctors have also charted oral antibiotics to commence tomorrow.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay, so the IV ABs running now at 100ml per hour.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Yes they are Running as charted; the next dose due as per the medication times. I’ve signed the last dose.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She’s very confused today. Observations have been stable, but she is febrile.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: otherwise she has stable obs but with a temperature. I’ll keep monitoring and encourage fluids as appropriate.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Thank you. No other acute issues to flag at the moment.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Hildy, you might feel a bit warm—we’re keeping a close eye on you. Are you in any pain right now?
[PATIENT]: I think I should be going home soon… where’s my coat?
[INCOMING_NURSE]: We’ll help you with that later. For now you’re safe here. The call bell is right by your hand, and we’ll be popping in regularly.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Plan for the shift: continue IV antibiotics as charted, monitor temperature and observations, and oral antibiotics to start tomorrow. We’ll also keep reorienting and maintain falls precautions given the confusion.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Perfect. Anything else you need before I head off, Hildy?
[PATIENT]: A cup of tea… maybe.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: I’ll check what you can have and come right back.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks for the handover.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: No worries. I’m off. See you both later.

example.text:
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Hi, handing over Mrs. Margaret Lewis, 85 years old, admitted with Alzheimer’s dementia and depression. She’s under Dr. Singh, Geriatrician.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks. Can you tell me about her current plan?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She has a dementia care plan in place. She becomes anxious during meals and ADLs, but has a positive Behaviour Support Plan documented in her file — strategies include step-by-step prompting, calm tone of voice, and family involvement at mealtimes.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: What’s her functional status?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She mobilises with a 4-wheel walker and supervision. Needs full assistance with showering and partial assistance with dressing. She eats better when family are present. They’ve been visiting twice daily, which helps settle her.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Current medications?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Escitalopram 10 mg, memantine 10 mg. No known allergies. She’s tolerating meds well.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Any monitoring or referrals?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She’s on food and fluid charts due to poor intake and has mild weight loss over the past 3 months. Awaiting medical review later today and Psych are planning to see her also. She’s also due for physio input to maintain mobility. Bowels charted — last motion yesterday.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Great. Anything else?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Just maintain orientation, continue strategies from her support plan, and liaise with her family who are due at 10AM. Pressure area care completed. All observations stable.

example.text:
[NURSE]: Hi, I’m handing over details for Mr. Luke Harris, a 42-year-old male who presented to ED following a deliberate overdose. He reportedly ingested approximately 50 Panadol tablets, 20 Serepax, and a bottle of whisky at home.
[PHARMACIST]: Thanks. What’s his current status?
[NURSE]: He’s currently drowsy but rousable, with slurred speech and intermittent agitation. He’s on 2 L/min oxygen via nasal prongs, with SpO? around 92%. GCS is 13. He’s under close observation and has IV access in place.
[PHARMACIST]: Have any treatments been initiated?
[NURSE]: Yes, we’ve started IV fluids (Normal Saline) and taken bloods for paracetamol levels, LFTs, and coagulation profile. We’re awaiting results to determine if N-acetylcysteine is required. No activated charcoal was given due to delayed presentation and reduced consciousness.
[PHARMACIST]: Any known allergies or regular medications?
[NURSE]: No known drug allergies. No regular medications documented at this stage. He’s a daily smoker and reports high alcohol intake.
[PHARMACIST]: Any concerns about interactions or toxicity?
[NURSE]: Yes, we’re concerned about hepatotoxicity from paracetamol, sedation from Serepax, and CNS depression from alcohol. He’s being monitored for respiratory compromise and liver function deterioration.
[PHARMACIST]: Thanks. I’ll review his chart and prepare for possible NAC administration. Let me know once the blood results are back.
[NURSE]: Will do. I’ll keep you updated on his clinical status and any changes.

example.text:
[ED Nurse]: Hi, I’m handing over Mr. Luke Harris, a 42-year-old male who presented to ED following a deliberate overdose. He reportedly ingested approximately 50 Panadol tablets, 20 Serepax, and a bottle of whisky at home after an argument with his partner.
[Paramedic]: Thanks. What’s his current condition?
[ED Nurse]: He arrived via ambulance, drowsy but rousable. He’s currently confused, slurred speech, and intermittently agitated. He’s on 2 L/min oxygen via nasal prongs, but his SpO? is sitting around 92%. He’s a smoker, and his respiratory rate is slightly depressed at 10–12 breaths per minute.
[Paramedic]: Any vitals or Q-ADDS score?
[ED Nurse]: Yes, latest observations: BP: 118/76, HR: 88 bpm, RR: 12, Temp: 36.5°C, SpO?: 92% on 2 L O?, GCS: 13 and a Q-ADDS score: 6 (due to RR, SpO?, confusion, and overdose)
[Paramedic]: Any IV access or treatment started?
[ED Nurse]: Yes, he has a 20G cannula in his right forearm, patent. We’ve started IV fluids (Normal Saline) and drawn bloods for paracetamol levels, LFTs, and coagulation profile. Activated charcoal was not given due to delayed presentation and reduced consciousness.
[Paramedic]: Any social concerns?
[ED Nurse]: Yes, he lives with his partner and has been in a verbal altercation prior to the overdose. He has no known mental health diagnosis, but this appears to be a first-time overdose. He has no children at home but reports high alcohol use and smoking daily.
[Paramedic]: Any plans for transfer?
[ED Nurse]: Yes, he’s being transferred to the medical ward for monitoring and possible N-acetylcysteine infusion pending paracetamol levels. Mental health team will review once medically stable.
[Paramedic]: Okay, I’ll update the receiving team and ensure safe transfer.

example.text:
[NURSE 1]: Hi, I’m handing over Mr. David Lee, 64 years old. He’s on the ward post-lobectomy and currently has a left-sided ICC in situ. It’s due to come out today.
[NURSE 2]: Okay, thanks. What’s the current status of the ICC?
[NURSE 1]: ICC has been on free drainage. Output over the last 24 hours is minimal — around 20 mL serous fluid. No air leak noted. Chest X-ray this morning shows good lung expansion. Surgical team reviewed and gave the okay for removal.
[NURSE 2]: Got it. Any pain or discomfort?
[NURSE 1]: He’s had some mild discomfort around the insertion site, but it’s well managed with regular paracetamol. No signs of infection — site is clean and dry.
[NURSE 2]: Any IV access?
[NURSE 1]: Yes, 20G cannula in the right forearm — patent and due for review tomorrow. He’s currently on oral meds only.
[NURSE 2]: I’ll check the med chart. Anything due?
[NURSE 1]: No meds due right now. He’s on regular analgesia and a stool softener. No known allergies.
[NURSE 2]: Any behavioural or cognitive concerns?
[NURSE 1]: No concerns. He’s alert, oriented, and understands the plan. He’s a bit anxious about the ICC removal, so just reassure him and let him know we’ll use local anaesthetic.
[NURSE 2]: Will do. I’ll prep the trolley and notify the team once it’s out.

example.text:
[ED Nurse]: Hi, I’m handing over Mr. Jack Thompson, a 45-year-old male who presented to ED following a chainsaw injury to his left lower leg sustained while working in forestry. The injury occurred approximately 90 minutes ago on-site.
[Paramedic]: Thanks. What’s his current condition?
[ED Nurse]: He’s alert and orientated, GCS 15. He’s in moderate pain but stable. The wound is deep, located on the anterolateral aspect of the left lower leg, with visible muscle and tissue damage. No active arterial bleeding, but there was significant blood loss at the scene.
[Paramedic]: Any neurovascular compromise?
[ED Nurse]:
We’ve done neurovascular obs: Sensation: Intact distal to the wound, Motor: Able to move toes, reduced strength in dorsiflexion, Capillary refill: less than 2 seconds, Pedal pulses: Present but slightly diminished compared to the right, Skin temp: Warm distally
We’re monitoring closely for compartment syndrome.
[Paramedic]: Any IV access?
[ED Nurse]: Yes, he has a 16G cannula in the right antecubital fossa, patent. He’s received 1 L Normal Saline IV and IV morphine 5 mg for pain relief.
[Paramedic]: Any other treatment so far?
[ED Nurse]: The wound has been irrigated and dressed with sterile gauze. Tetanus status is unknown—awaiting confirmation. Bloods have been taken including FBC, coagulation, and crossmatch. He’s Nil by mouth and awaiting surgical review.
[Paramedic]: Any other concerns?
[ED Nurse]: He’s a smoker, no known drug allergies, and has no significant medical history. He’s anxious but cooperative. We’ve contacted his workplace and next of kin.
[Paramedic]: Thanks. I’ll ensure safe transfer and continue monitoring neurovascular status en route

example.text:
[Outgoing Nurse]: Hi, I’m handing over Mrs. Dorothy Lane in bed 5. She’s an 83-year-old patient admitted with a left neck of femur fracture following a fall at home. She’s post-op day 1 following internal fixation. She’s currently confused, intermittently orientated, and requires full assistance with care.
[Incoming Nurse]: Thanks. What’s her current Q-ADDS score?
[Outgoing Nurse]: Her Q-ADDS score is 5—due to confusion, elevated respiratory rate, and low urine output. Latest observations: BP: 118/72, HR: 96 bpm, RR: 22, Temp: 36.9°C, SpO?: 95% on room air, she’s Alert but confused.
[Incoming Nurse]: Any pressure area concerns?
[Outgoing Nurse]: Yes, she has a chronic venous leg ulcer on her right lower leg. It’s being dressed with Iodosorb and a foam dressing, reviewed by wound care yesterday. No sacral or heel breakdown noted. She’s on a pressure-relieving mattress and being repositioned every 2 hours.
[Incoming Nurse]: Is she continent?
[Outgoing Nurse]: No, she’s incontinent of urine and has an IDC in place—draining clear urine, ~400 mL over the last 6 hours. She’s also on a bowel chart—no bowel movement today, last opened bowels yesterday.
[Incoming Nurse]: Any vascular obs?
[Outgoing Nurse]: Yes, we’re doing neurovascular obs on the affected limb: Sensation: Intact, Movement: Limited due to pain, Cap refill: less than 2 seconds, Pedal pulses: Present, Skin temp: Warm.
[Incoming Nurse]: Any IV access or medications?
[Outgoing Nurse]: She has a 20G cannula in her right forearm, patent.
Medications include: IV Cefazolin 1g TDS, Paracetamol 1g QID, PRN Endone 2.5–5 mg Enoxaparin 40 mg SC daily, No known drug allergies.
[Incoming Nurse]: Thanks. I’ll continue pressure care, monitor her Q-ADDS, and update wound and fluid charts.

example.text:
[NURSE]: Hi Dr. Patel, I need you to review Mr. Raymond Ellis in bed 6. He’s a 68-year-old patient with severe systolic heart failure; EF is 20% on echo. He’s currently being monitored for ventricular arrhythmias and has an irregular heart rate. Cardiology has flagged him for ICD placement pending further assessment.
[DOCTOR]: Thanks. What’s his current clinical status?
[NURSE]: He’s on dobutamine at 5 mcg/kg/min and dopamine at 3 mcg/kg/min for inotropic support. He’s on continuous cardiac monitoring—rhythm is irregular, mostly junctional with occasional ectopics. He’s alert but fatigued.
[DOCTOR]: What are his latest observations?
[NURSE]: BP: 94/58, HR: 108 bpm, irregular, RR: 22, Temp: 36.6°C, SpO?: 94% on 2 L O?, and a Q-ADDS score: 7 (HR, BP, RR, cardiac rhythm).
[DOCTOR]: Any fluid balance concerns?
[NURSE]: Yes, he’s fluid overloaded. His Input (last 24h): ~2200 mL (IV + oral) the Output: ~1200 mL (IDC), the total balance:  plus 1000 mL
He’s on a fluid restriction chart and daily weights. Legs are oedematous and he’s on 2-hourly pressure area care with a pressure-relieving mattress.
[DOCTOR]: Any other monitoring?
[NURSE]: Yes, we’re doing neurovascular obs and cardiac telemetry. He has a 22G cannula in the left forearm, patent. IDC is draining clear urine. No bowel movement today—on a bowel chart.
[DOCTOR]: Medications?
[NURSE]: IV Dobutamine & Dopamine as mentioned, Frusemide 40 mg IV BD, Bisoprolol 2.5 mg daily, Spironolactone 25 mg daily, Paracetamol 1g QID PRN
No known drug allergies.
[DOCTOR]: Thanks. I’ll review him now and speak with cardiology regarding ICD timing and ongoing inotropic support.
[NURSE]: Great. I’ll continue monitoring and update fluid and Q-ADDS charts.

example.text:
[Outgoing Nurse]: Hi, I’m handing over Mr. Kyle Jensen in bed 3. He’s a 29-year-old male admitted through ED last night following a stab wound to the left lower abdomen. He’s currently stable but requires ongoing wound care and IV medications.
[Incoming Nurse]: Thanks. What’s the current status of the wound?
[Outgoing Nurse]: The wound is approximately 4 cm in length, deep but not penetrating any major organs. It was cleaned and sutured in ED. There’s mild swelling and bruising around the site, but no signs of active bleeding or infection. Dressing is intact and due for review this afternoon.
[Incoming Nurse]: Any neurovascular concerns?
[Outgoing Nurse]: Neurovascular obs are normal his Sensation and movement in lower limbs are intact, the Capillary refill less than 2 seconds, and there are No signs of vascular compromise.
[Incoming Nurse]: What medications is he on?
[Outgoing Nurse]: He’s currently on: IV Ceftriaxone 1g daily, IV Paracetamol 1g QID, PRN Morphine 2.5–5 mg SC for pain he has No known drug allergies.
[Incoming Nurse]: Any other monitoring?
[Outgoing Nurse]: Yes: a Fluid Balance Chart: Input ~1200 mL, Output ~900 mL (urine via voiding), he has a Q-ADDS score: Currently 3 (due to pain and elevated HR) His vitals are stable. 
[Incoming Nurse]: Any psychosocial concerns?
[Outgoing Nurse]: He’s cooperative but anxious. Police have been notified due to the nature of the injury. No visitors currently. Social work referral has been made.
[Incoming Nurse]: Thanks. I’ll continue wound care, monitor his IV therapy, and update his charts.

example.text:
[NURSE]: Good morning, Dr. Chen. I’d like to hand over Mr. Robert Hayes in bed 12. He’s a 72-year-old patient with congestive heart failure, admitted three days ago with worsening dyspnoea and peripheral oedema. His ejection fraction is 30%, confirmed on echo.
[DOCTOR]: Thanks. Mr. Hayes, how are you feeling this morning?
[PATIENT]: Still a bit short of breath, especially when I move around. My legs feel heavy.
[NURSE]: He’s been on IV frusemide 40 mg BD, and we’ve seen some improvement in his fluid balance. His Input (last 24h) is  1200 mL his Output is  1800 mL via IDC. His total balance is -600 mL. He’s on a fluid restriction of 1.5 L/day and a low-sodium diet.
[DOCTOR]: Any changes in observations?
[NURSE]: Yes, latest obs: BP: 110/70, HR: 88 bpm, RR: 20, SpO?: 94% on room air, Temp: 36.7°C and a Q-ADDS score:  of 4 (due to RR and ongoing symptoms). He’s been repositioned 2-hourly, and we’re maintaining pressure area care with a pressure-relieving mattress. No skin breakdown noted.
[DOCTOR]: Any concerns with medications or tolerance?
[NURSE]: He’s tolerating oral meds well he has No known drug allergies.
[PATIENT]: Doctor, do you think I’ll be going home soon?
[DOCTOR]: We’re seeing good progress, Mr. Hayes. We’ll continue monitoring your fluid status and symptoms. If things keep improving, we’ll start planning for discharge with community follow-up.
[NURSE]: I’ll continue monitoring his Q-ADDS, fluid balance, and skin integrity. Would you like a repeat blood panel today?
[DOCTOR]: Yes, let’s check renal function and electrolytes again. Thanks.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Good morning, Ms. Carter. I’m Jack, and I’ll be your nurse for today. We’ll do a quick bedside handover with my colleague, if that’s okay.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Hi, Ms. Carter. This is the nurse taking over for the day. Could you please confirm your full name?
[PATIENT]: Emily Carter.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Thank you. This is Ms. Emily Carter in Bed 6, Room 14, aged 29, under Dr. Thompson, General Surgeon.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Ms. Carter is Day 1 post-op from a laparoscopic appendectomy. She returned from theatre yesterday afternoon. Her vital signs have remained stable overnight. She’s currently tolerating oral fluids and has transitioned to a light diet this morning.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Pain is being managed with regular oral analgesia. No nausea or vomiting reported. Her wound sites are clean and dry, with dressings intact. She’s mobilised to the bathroom with assistance and tolerated it well.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Ms. Carter, how are you feeling this morning? Any pain or discomfort?
[PATIENT]: Just a bit sore around the belly, but otherwise okay.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Pain score was 3/10 on movement earlier. Dr. Thompson reviewed her this morning and is happy with her progress. Discharge planning will depend on how she tolerates diet and mobilises today.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: I’ll keep monitoring your pain and mobility and check in with Dr. Thompson’s team later today. Is there anything you need before we finish handover?
[PATIENT]: No, I’m fine for now.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Please use the call bell if you need anything. I’ll leave you in good hands.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: I’ll be back shortly to check your observations and review your chart, Ms. Carter.

example.text:
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Good morning, Ms. Bennett. I’m Jack, and I’ll be your nurse for today. We’ll do a quick bedside handover with my colleague, if that’s okay.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Hi, Ms. Bennett. This is the nurse taking over for the day. Could you please confirm your full name?
[PATIENT]: Rachel Bennett.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Thank you. This is Ms. Rachel Bennett in Bed 2, Room 9, aged 52, under Dr. Wallace, Oncology Consultant.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Ms. Bennett is currently receiving cycle 3 of chemotherapy for breast cancer. She’s had mild nausea overnight, managed with antiemetics. Her vitals are stable, and she’s tolerating oral fluids. Bloods were taken this morning for routine monitoring.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She’s expressed feeling emotionally overwhelmed and worried about managing work and home responsibilities during treatment. A social worker referral was made, and they’re scheduled to visit later this morning.
[SOCIAL WORKER]: Hi Rachel, I’m Priya, one of the hospital social workers. I understand you’re going through a lot right now, and I’m here to support you. Is it okay if we talk for a few minutes?
[PATIENT]: Yes, please. I’ve been struggling a bit.
[SOCIAL WORKER]: Thank you. I know chemotherapy can be physically and emotionally exhausting. You mentioned concerns about work and home—can you tell me a bit more about what’s been difficult?
[PATIENT]: I’m a single mum, and I’ve had to take time off work. I’m worried about bills and keeping things stable for my daughter.
[SOCIAL WORKER]: That’s completely understandable. We can explore options for financial support, community services, and counselling. I can also help connect you with support groups for women going through similar experiences. Would that be helpful?
[PATIENT]: Yes, I think so. I just don’t know where to start.
[SOCIAL WORKER]: That’s okay—I'll walk you through it. You’re not alone in this, and we’ll make sure you have the support you need.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: I’ll check back in shortly, Ms. Bennett, and coordinate with Priya and Dr. Wallace’s team. Please use the call bell if you need anything.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Good morning, Mr. Thompson. I’m Jack, and I’ll be your nurse for today. We’ll do a quick bedside handover with my colleague, if that’s okay.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Hi, Mr. Thompson. This is the nurse taking over for the day. Could you please confirm your full name?
[PATIENT]: Peter Thompson.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Thank you. This is Mr. Peter Thompson in Bed 6, Room 4, aged 78, under Dr. Ellis, General Medicine.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Mr. Thompson was brought into ED yesterday by his wife due to severe constipation and abdominal discomfort. He had not opened his bowels for 6 days and was experiencing bloating and reduced appetite. His wife, who is also elderly, was struggling to manage his care at home.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He was assessed in ED, given a fleet enema and started on oral laxatives. Abdominal X-ray showed significant faecal loading but no obstruction. He’s now admitted for bowel management and monitoring. Vitals are stable. No nausea or vomiting overnight.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He’s had one small bowel motion early this morning. Pain score was 3/10. He’s tolerating fluids and has been mobilising with assistance.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Mr. Thompson, how are you feeling this morning? Any relief after the bowel motion?
[PATIENT]: A little better, still a bit uncomfortable.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He’s aware of the plan and has been cooperative. His wife is quite anxious and has asked to speak with someone about support at home. A social worker referral has been made to assess home care needs and carer support.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: I’ll follow up with the social work team and check in with Dr. Ellis’s team regarding next steps. Is there anything you need before we finish handover?
[PATIENT]: No, I’m okay.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Please use the call bell if you need anything. I’ll leave you in good hands.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: I’ll be back shortly to check your observations and review your chart, Mr. Thompson.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Good morning, Mr. Fraser. I’m Jack, and I’ll be your nurse for today. We’ll just do a quick bedside handover with my colleague, if that’s alright.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Hi, Mr. Fraser. Could you please confirm your full name?
[PATIENT]: Andrew Fraser.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Thank you and your date of birth? 
[PATIENT]: Twenty-third of August 1958. 
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Great and your URN on that armband says 893745 that matches your chart. So Mr Fraser is under the cardiothoracic surgeon covering this list - not sure who.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He was admitted yesterday for a planned aortic valve replacement due to severe aortic stenosis. He’s currently stable, nil by mouth, and awaiting theatre — I think the procedure’s still set for this afternoon, though final time hasn’t been confirmed yet. Pre‑op bloods and ECG were done and look okay from what I saw, but anaesthetics still need to recheck his potassium levels. Consent’s signed and documented.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He’s on his regular cardiac medications — they were reviewed by the anaesthetics registrar this morning, or possibly one of the fellows. No chest pain or shortness of breath that he’s mentioned overnight. Vitals all fine — around baseline. He’s aware of the procedure and quite anxious, understandably; I reassured him but might be worth chatting again before transfer.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Mr. Fraser, how are you feeling this morning? Any discomfort or anything worrying you?
[PATIENT]: Just nervous, really. No pain.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Of course. His wife’s planning to come in later today — she wasn’t sure what time yet. Theatre team should ring the ward once they’ve finalised scheduling, but I haven’t heard back this morning. He’s got family contact details in the chart if anyone needs to update them.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks. I’ll follow up with the surgical team and confirm timing when possible. Is there anything you need before we finish handover?
[PATIENT]: No, I’m okay.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Great. Please use the call bell if you need anything. I’ll be finishing soon, but the coordinator’s around if anything changes.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thank you. I’ll come back shortly to check your obs and review your chart, Mr. Fraser.

example.text:
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Good morning, Mr. Jackson. I’m Sarah, and I’ll be your nurse for today. We’ll do a quick bedside handover with my colleague, if that’s okay.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Hi, Mr. Jackson. This is the nurse taking over for the day. Could you please confirm your full name?
[PATIENT]: David Jackson.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Thank you. This is Mr. David Jackson in Bed 4, Room 6, aged 64, under Dr. Patel, Orthopaedic Consultant.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Mr. Jackson is awaiting ORIF surgery for a left femoral neck fracture, scheduled for tomorrow. He’s been stable overnight, but this morning he reported lower abdominal discomfort and has not passed urine since yesterday evening.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Bladder scan showed retention of 650 mL. Medical team reviewed and requested an IDC insertion. He’s alert, cooperative, and understands the procedure. No known allergies. Pain is currently 3/10 on movement.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Mr. Jackson, I’ll be inserting a catheter shortly to help relieve the pressure in your bladder. I’ll explain everything before we begin.
[PATIENT]: Okay, thank you. It’s really uncomfortable.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: I understand. I’ll get everything ready now.
[SARAH]: Hey, Jess—sorry to interrupt. I’ve got a patient in Room 6 with urinary retention and needs an IDC. I haven’t done one before—would you mind assisting or supervising?
[JESS]: Of course, happy to help. Let’s grab the trolley and go through it together. I’ll walk you through the steps.
[SARAH]: Thanks so much. I’ve read the protocol, just haven’t had the chance to do one hands-on yet.
[JESS]: No worries—we’ll take it slow and make sure Mr. Jackson is comfortable throughout.
[NURSE SARAH]: Hi Mr. Jackson, I just wanted to check in. I understand you’re still feeling quite uncomfortable.
[PATIENT]: Yes, I still haven’t been able to pass urine. It’s getting worse.
[NURSE SARAH]: I’m sorry to hear that. We’ve done a bladder scan and it shows you’re retaining quite a bit—over 700 mL. The doctor will be coming shortly to insert a catheter to relieve the pressure.
[PATIENT]: Okay, thank you.
[NURSE SARAH]: Hi Dr. Patel, sorry to interrupt. Mr. Jackson in Room 6 has urinary retention—bladder scan shows 740 mL. I attempted an IDC but met resistance and he was quite uncomfortable. Would you be able to insert it?
[DR. PATEL]: Yes, I can do that. Can you get the trolley set up and let me know when it’s ready?
[NURSE SARAH]: Absolutely. I’ll prepare the sterile field now.
[NURSE SARAH]: Dr. Patel, the trolley is set up and Mr. Jackson has been informed. He’s ready when you are.
[DR. PATEL]: Great, let’s go ahead. Can you assist with maintaining the sterile field?
[NURSE SARAH]: Of course.

[NURSE AMY]: Good morning, Ms. Carter. I’m Amy, and I’ll be your nurse for today. We’ll do a quick bedside handover with my colleague, if that’s okay.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Hi, Ms. Carter. This is the nurse taking over for the day. Could you please confirm your full name?
[PATIENT]: Jessica Carter.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Thank you. This is Ms. Jessica Carter in Bed 5, Room 11, aged 35, under Dr. Nguyen, Orthopaedic Consultant.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Ms. Carter was admitted yesterday following a fall at home. She has a displaced fracture of the right humerus and is scheduled for ORIF surgery tomorrow morning. She’s currently in a sling and on regular analgesia. Pain score was 6/10 earlier, now 3/10 after medication.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Neurovascular obs are intact: her Capillary refill <2 seconds, Sensation present, her Movement limited due to pain but preserved, there is No swelling or discoloration noted
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She’s a single mother of two young children and has expressed concern about managing at home post-op. A social worker referral has been made to explore home support and childcare options.
[PHYSIOTHERAPIST]: Hi Jessica, I’m Priya from physio. I’ve reviewed your chart and will work with you post-op to help regain movement and strength in your arm. For now, just rest and keep the arm supported. After surgery, we’ll start gentle exercises and discuss strategies for managing daily tasks one-handed.
[PATIENT]: Okay, I’m worried about how I’ll manage with the kids.
[PHYSIOTHERAPIST]: That’s understandable. We’ll work closely with the social worker and nursing team to make sure you have the right support in place.
[SOCIAL WORKER]: Hi Jessica, I’m Mark from social work. I understand you’re concerned about managing at home after surgery. Can you tell me a bit about your current support system?
[PATIENT]: It’s just me and the kids. My mum lives interstate and I don’t have anyone nearby.
[SOCIAL WORKER]: Thanks for sharing. I’ll look into short-term home care options and community support services. We can also explore childcare assistance while you recover. I’ll keep you updated and help with any paperwork.
[NURSE AMY]: I’ll continue monitoring your pain and neurovascular status, and coordinate with the surgical team. Let me know if you need anything, Jessica.
[PATIENT]: Thank you. I really appreciate it.

example.text:
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Hi, I’M Brad am I’m handing over bed 12, Mrs. Maria Giannopoulos, 81 years old. She’s been admitted for severe symptomatic aortic stenosis and is scheduled for a TAVI tomorrow morning.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks. What’s happening currently?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She’s stable. No chest pain or syncope overnight. She’s NYHA Class III—gets breathless on minimal exertion. Vitals are within normal limits, and she’s on telemetry. No arrhythmias noted.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Has she been reviewed by the team?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Yes, cardiology and interventional have reviewed. She’s been consented, and the procedure is booked for 8:00 AM. She’s fasting from midnight. Pre-op checklist is complete.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Any comorbidities?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Yes—hypertension, chronic kidney disease stage 3, and mild cognitive impairment. She’s on perindopril, frusemide, and aspirin. No known allergies.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Any communication needs?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: English is her second language—Greek is her first. She understands most things but prefers slow, clear explanations. Interpreter has been arranged for the morning. Her son is her substitute decision-maker and has been involved in all discussions.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Any concerns overnight?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She was a bit anxious about the procedure but settled after reassurance. No acute issues. She’s continent, mobilising with assistance, and on a low-sodium diet.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Got it. I’ll keep her calm and prep her for theatre in the morning.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Perfect. Let me know if anything changes. All documentation is up to date, including the consent and pre-op orders.

example.text:
[OUTGOING ED NURSE]: Hi, i'm handing over bed 4, Ms. Aisha Patel, 34 years old. She’s presented to ED with acute gastroenteritis—onset was about 24 hours ago.
[INCOMING WARD NURSE]: Thanks. What are her main symptoms?
[OUTGOING ED NURSE]: Profuse watery diarrhoea—about 6 episodes in the last 12 hours—and 3 episodes of vomiting. No blood in stool. She’s had mild abdominal cramping and reports feeling dizzy when standing.
[INCOMING WARD NURSE]: What’s been done in ED?
[OUTGOING ED NURSE]: She’s been rehydrated with 2 litres of IV normal saline. Bloods were taken—U&Es show mild hypokalaemia, which we’ve started correcting. Stool sample has been sent. She’s afebrile, and vitals are now stable—BP 108/70, HR 92, afebrile, RR 18, SpO? 99% on room air.
[INCOMING WARD NURSE]: Any medications?
[OUTGOING ED NURSE]: Ondansetron 4 mg IV given with good effect. She’s tolerating sips of water now. No antibiotics charted at this stage—awaiting stool results. Electrolyte replacement is charted.
[INCOMING WARD NURSE]: Any comorbidities or allergies?
[OUTGOING ED NURSE]: No known medical history. No regular medications. NKDA.
[INCOMING WARD NURSE]: Any communication or social needs?
[OUTGOING ED NURSE]: English is her first language. Lives alone, works as a teacher. She’s a bit embarrassed about the symptoms but otherwise coping well. Prefers a female nurse if possible.
[INCOMING WAR DNURSE]: Got it. I’ll continue fluids, monitor output, and keep an eye on her electrolytes.
[OUTGOING ED NURSE]: Perfect. Let me know if she deteriorates or becomes febrile. All documentation is up to date, including fluid balance and stool chart.

example.text:
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Hi, I’m handing over bed 8, Mr. Angelo Romano, 84 years old. He’s in for a TAVI via left subclavian access, scheduled for tomorrow morning. He’s now developed a new arrhythmia—I’ve notified the medical team.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay—what kind of arrhythmia?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He went into new-onset atrial fibrillation about an hour ago—irregularly irregular rhythm, HR peaked at 130. He’s asymptomatic but more confused than usual. No chest pain or syncope. ECG has been done and uploaded.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: What’s been done so far?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: The cardiology registrar has been notified and is reviewing. We’ve done a full set of bloods including U&Es, magnesium, and troponin. He’s on telemetry and we’re monitoring closely. No rate control started yet—awaiting medical orders.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: What’s his baseline?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Normally in sinus rhythm. He’s got known aortic stenosis and mild cognitive impairment. He’s also incontinent of urine—currently in pads. No IDC.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: IV access?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Two good IVs—18G in the right forearm and 20G in the left hand. Maintenance fluids running at 75 mL/hr. He’s fasting from midnight for the procedure.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Medications?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Regular meds include frusemide, aspirin, and atorvastatin. No anticoagulants yet—this will likely be reviewed post-TAVI. PRN paracetamol and haloperidol are charted. No known allergies.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Any support needs?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: English is his second language—Italian is his first. Interpreter is booked for tomorrow. His daughter is his next of kin and has been very involved. He’s quite anxious and confused, especially with the new arrhythmia.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Got it. I’ll keep monitoring his rhythm and wait for the plan from cardiology.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Perfect. Let me know if his condition worsens—especially if he becomes hypotensive or more confused. All documentation is up to date, including ECG, fluid balance, and neuro obs.

example.text:
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Hi, I’m handing over bed 5, Ms. Carol Tan, 72 years old. She was admitted for a permanent pacemaker insertion due to symptomatic bradycardia. The procedure was done this morning, but she’s developed a left-sided pneumothorax post-op.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Oh no—how was it picked up?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She became short of breath and desaturated to 89% on room air about an hour post-procedure. Chest X-ray confirmed a moderate pneumothorax. The cardiology team has reviewed, and a chest drain has been inserted—left side, mid-axillary line.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: How is she now?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: More comfortable. She’s on 2 L nasal prongs—sats are now 96%. Drain is on low suction and swinging well. No signs of tension. Vitals are stable—BP 122/70, HR 78 (paced), RR 20, Temp 36.7.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: IV access?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: One 20G in the right forearm—patent. She’s on maintenance IV fluids—normal saline at 75 mL/hr. No IV antibiotics charted at this stage.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Medications?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Regular meds include metoprolol, atorvastatin, and aspirin. She’s had paracetamol for mild post-op pain. No known allergies. Analgesia and PRNs are charted.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Any other concerns?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She’s a bit anxious and tearful—understandably shaken by the complication. English is her first language. She’s continent and mobilising with assistance. Physio has been informed for post-drain mobility review.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Got it. I’ll monitor the drain, pain, and oxygen needs closely.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Perfect. Let the team know if there’s any increase in respiratory distress or if the drain output changes significantly. All documentation is up to date, including drain chart, obs, and post-op notes.

example.text:
[WARD_NURSE]: Hi, thanks for coming to see Mr. Alan Brooks in bed 12. He’s Day 1 post-CABG, just transferred from ICU this morning. He’s stable but still has several attachments in place, so we’ll need to be cautious with mobility.
[PHYSIOTHERAPIST]: Can you give me a quick overview?
[WARD_NURSE]: Sure. He had a triple vessel CABG yesterday. He’s currently on: IV dopamine, weaning at 0.05 mcg/kg/min, currently running at 3 mcg/min, he has a CVL in the right internal jugular, there are Three chest drains still in situ. He has an IDC draining clear urine, Telemetry monitoring active. 
[PHYSIOTHERAPIST]: Okay. Is he alert and able to follow instructions?
[WARD_NURSE]: Yes, he’s alert, orientated, and cooperative. Pain is well-managed with paracetamol and PRN oxycodone. He’s keen to mobilise but understandably anxious.
[PHYSIOTHERAPIST]: Any precautions I should be aware of?
[WARD_NURSE]: Yes—sternal precautions apply. No pushing or pulling with arms, no lifting above shoulder height. We’ll need to support the chest drains and CVL during movement. IDC can be secured to the leg.
[PHYSIOTHERAPIST]: Any recent obs or concerns?
[WARD_NURSE]:
Vitals are stable: BP: 104/68, HR: 88 bpm, sinus rhythm, SpO?: 96% on room air
No dizziness or desaturation noted. He’s due for obs in 30 minutes.
[PHYSIOTHERAPIST]: I’ll start with a gentle sit-out and breathing exercises and reassess tolerance. I’ll liaise with the team about progressing mobility tomorrow.
[WARD_NURSE]: Perfect. Let me know if you need help with attachments or if anything changes.

example.text:
[NIGHT_NURSE]: Morning. Handing over Mrs. Evelyn Taylor, 81 years old, in bed 7. Evelyn, this is Nurse Mia, who’ll be looking after you today.
[MORNING_NURSE]: Hi Evelyn, I’ll be your nurse this morning. How are you feeling?
[PATIENT]: I feel a bit strange. My right arm feels heavy, and I’m having trouble speaking clearly.
[NIGHT_NURSE]: That’s actually new. She was drowsy overnight, but I thought it was just fatigue. I didn’t notice any clear deficits during the night, but she’s now showing slurred speech and right-sided weakness. I’ve just done a quick neuro check—there’s a facial droop and reduced grip on the right.
[MORNING_NURSE]: That sounds like a possible stroke. Has the doctor been notified?
[NIGHT_NURSE]: Not yet—I picked it up just before handover. I was about to escalate. She’s on Q-ADDS, scoring 6 now—due to new neuro changes and slightly elevated BP (162/94). HR 84, RR 18, SpO? 97% on room air, Temp 36.6.
[MORNING_NURSE]: Okay, I’ll call the medical registrar immediately and start hourly neuro obs.
[DOCTOR]: (enters) I’ve just been informed. Evelyn, I’m Dr. Singh. We’re concerned you may have had a stroke overnight, and we’re going to do some urgent tests, including a CT scan.
[PATIENT]: Oh… I didn’t realise. I just thought I was tired.
[DOCTOR]: You did the right thing by speaking up. We’ll take care of you.
[MORNING_NURSE]: I’ll stay with her and start the neuro obs now. Is she nil by mouth?
[DOCTOR]: Yes, keep her NPO until we assess her swallow. I’ll organise an urgent stroke team review.
[NIGHT_NURSE]: She’s on a fluid balance chart, and her oral intake was minimal overnight. No IV fluids running yet. She’s on regular antihypertensives and aspirin. No known allergies.
[MORNING_NURSE]: Got it. I’ll update the family once we have a clearer picture.
[NIGHT_NURSE]: Thanks. All documentation is up to date—Q-ADDS, med chart, and fluid balance.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Bed 5 is Layla Sonia Da Silva. Layla, this is George who is the day nurse and will be looking after you.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Hi, Layla. We’ll do a quick bedside handover with you.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Could you tell us your full name, just to confirm who you are.
[PATIENT]: Layla Sonia Da Silva.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Thanks, Layla. So, Layla is 34 years old, admitted under Dr. Liu for management of her diabetes.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Her past history is: type 1 diabetes since childhood and hypertension.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She’s independent and ambulant on the ward, she is self-caring with her own blood glucose checks and insulin.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Layla, are you comfortable checking your BGLs and giving your insulin yourself?
[PATIENT]: Yes, I’ve been doing it for a long time.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Her insulin is on a sliding scale/variable dose. We confirm each dose with the doctor based on her current BGL.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Her morning sugars have been trending high, so the team still needs to review and possibly adjust the regimen.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Her Blood pressure has been in the high-normal range around 140/84; also for team review.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She’s still for a referral to the diabetes educator.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: There are no other problems noted.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay, I will 
- Touch base with the team about the morning highs and her BP.
- Clarify the next insulin dose with the doctor.
- Follow up the diabetic educator referral and see when they are coming.
- Continue to document her BGLs and insulin administration. 
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Layla, is there anything you need right now or anything you’d like to add?
[PATIENT]: No, I’m okay. Thanks.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Great. We’ll check in again after I speak with the team.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Good Morning, Scott. I’m Alex, I’ll be looking after you today. I’m just getting bedside handover from Mia, is that okay?
[PATIENT]: Sure.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: I’ll just check your ID band. Iv Cannula and heparin infusion, Thank you.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: This is Scott Rogers, 66 years old, In Bed 2 and is under Dr Dalianis. He came in with chest pain and coronary artery narrowing. He’s for a procedure later today.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Is he prepped?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Yes—pre‑op checklist is completed and filed at the front of the chart. An ECG has been done and looks normal. He’s in a gown and ready to go.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Fasting status?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Fasted from midnight for the procedure.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: And the planned procedure?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Depending on the blockage, they may do a stent or balloon angioplasty; CABG is also on the consent. The consent form is in the chart.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Observations?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: All observations are stable.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Great, we’ll keep you fasted and ready, Scott, and we’ll send you when they call for you.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Scott, do you need anything for comfort right now?
[PATIENT]: I’m okay, thanks.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: All right. I’ll keep an eye on your observations and paperwork. Mia, anything else?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: That’s all for him.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks, Mia. Scott, press the call bell if you need us. I’ll be back shortly.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Good Morning, Martin. I’m Priya, I’ll be looking after you today. I’m just getting handover from Alex who’s been on nights, is that okay?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Hi, Martin. We’ll keep this brief. This is Bed 4, Martin Cavedon, 73, under Dr. Sanchez.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Martin, could you tell us your full name and age, please?
[PATIENT]: Martin Cavedon, I’m 73.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Do you have any medication allergies?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: There is nothing documented in the chart.
[PATIENT]: No, none that I know of.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Martin came in with chest pain. He has a long history of heart problems, asthma, and GORD.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay. Any chest pain at the moment, Martin?
[PATIENT]: No, it’s settled now.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Earlier he reported chest pain; he was given two Anginine with good effect, then a dose of morphine. He’s stable now and was monitored accordingly. [INCOMING_NURSE]:  Are observations up to date?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Yes, all obs are charted with a QADDS of zero. ECG was taken as well no new changes.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Was there any Blood taken to check the troponin level?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Yes, Blood results have just arrived in the system and are pending medical review. Please call the doctor to review them.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: I’ll page Dr. Sanchez’s team after we finish here.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: The plans it that he’s for a carotid ultrasound, this needs to be arranged, and an echocardiogram at some stage.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Martin, if the chest pain comes back, please press your call bell straight away.
[PATIENT]: I will, thanks.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Anything you need before we go, water or to adjust the bed?
[PATIENT]: I’m fine, thank you.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: That’s everything from me.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks, Alex. I’ll get onto the doctors about the bloods and start organising the scans.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Good morning, Lucila. I’m the day nurse coming on. We’ll do a quick bedside handover with my colleague, if that’s okay.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Morning. This is bed 6, Ms. Lucila Marlor, 88 years old, who is under Dr. Sanchez.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Hi Ms. Marlor. We’re just talking about you so we can plan your care today.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Lucila was admitted five days ago with a suspected overdose. She lives in a retirement facility. She’s been improving since admission.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay, Any change in how much help she needs?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She needs minimal assistance with ADLs—same as previously noted.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: so she's minimal assist with activities of daily living?

[INCOMING_NURSE]: No worries, we’ll make sure you’ve got the help you need.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Any other issues overnight?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: No new issues reported. She is continuing to improve.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks. Is there a plan for today?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: To continue current care, assist with ADLs as needed, and await Dr. Sanchez’s review.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Perfect. Ms. Marlor, we’ll check on you regularly. Use your call bell if you need anything between visits.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Good Morning, Maria. We’re just going to do your bedside handover with the day nurse now.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Hi Maria, I’ll be looking after you today. Could you confirm your full name for me?
[PATIENT]: Maria Clemens.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thank you.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: This is Maria, 79 years old, under Dr. Chanson. She came in with shortness of breath on exertion.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Goals of care: NFR not for resus and not for MET, as per the chart.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay is that filed in her chart?

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Yes. She has multiple allergies (documented on the chart and band). She’s on regular inhaler puffers and a high dose of prednisolone.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She’s having daily random capillary BGLs.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay, I’ll make sure the BGL is checked today and meds given per chart.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Mobility-wise, she walks independently with a wheely walker.
[PATIENT]: Yes, I manage fine with it.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She’s awaiting team review and an OT review; physio is ongoing.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Observations have been stable. Noted nail changes on assessment. 
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Maria, how’s your breathing right now — any shortness of breath at rest?
[PATIENT]: It’s okay while I’m sitting. Worse when I walk.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: I’ll keep an eye on that and pace activities.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: The plan is to continue regular puffers and prednisolone, daily random BGLs, await medical team and OT reviews, continue physio, mobilise with the wheely walker as tolerated.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: I’ll ensure allergy precautions are in place and the call bell is within reach.
[PATIENT]: Thank you.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Anything else you need before we finish, Maria?
[PATIENT]: No, I’m fine.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: That’s everything from me. Thanks.

example.text:
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Hi Mindy. I’m Sam, I’ll be looking after you today. I’m just getting handover from Alex, is that okay?
[PATIENT]: Sure.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Thanks, Mindy. So, bed 2 is Mindy Jasmine Parks, 34 years old, under Dr. Cox.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Hi Mindy, could you confirm your full name for us?
[PATIENT]: Mindy Jasmine Parks.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thank you. I’ve checked your wristband—details match the chart and you have had all your medications for now. 

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Mindy has recurrent lung cancer with chest pain and a cough. She had lung cancer five years ago. she was also a heavy smoker for about 10 years.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay. Is she still smoking or has she given up?

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She has given up. She had bloods taken this morning and I haven’t checked if the results are back yet. From the doctors’ ward round, my understanding is they weren’t great, but I don’t have the specifics. This will need to be  followed-up.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: No Problem, I’ll chase the blood results and review the notes/orders after this.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Her family is in attendance.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Her observations were stable for my whole shift so QADDS equals zero.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Is she on  any oxygen or telemetry?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: No, just routine monitoring. She’s for further monitoring today.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Mindy’s been uncomfortable lying down.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Mindy, are you still uncomfortable when flat?
[PATIENT]: Yes, it’s worse when I lie back.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay, we can sit you up more and use extra pillows—let us know what’s most comfortable. Any chest pain right now?
[PATIENT]: A little, mostly when I lie down.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks, let the team know if it changes and I can get you some pain relief.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She’s self-caring and ambulant.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Great.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Any meds or infusions I need to be aware of?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: No nothing at the moment.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: That’s everything I need to tell you.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks, Alex.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: The plan for today is to continue monitoring her observations, follow up today’s blood results and the medical plan with Dr. Cox’s team, manage comfort—keep Mindy more upright for breathing and chest discomfort, and keep family informed. Mindy, please buzz if the chest pain worsens or you feel more short of breath.
[PATIENT]: Okay, thank you.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Anything else you need before I go, Mindy?
[PATIENT]: No, I’m okay.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: I’ll be back shortly after I check those results.

example.text:
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Good Morning, Amanda. I’m Dorothy the day nurse. I’ll just get handover from Oliver, then we’ll check in with you.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Hi Dorothy. In Bed 3 is Amanda Agatha Phillips, who is 76 years old.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Amanda, can you tell us your full name and date of birth?
[PATIENT]: I… I’m not sure… sorry.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: That’s okay, I’ll check your wristband. Amanda Agatha Phillips, 76. Thanks.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]:She has a history of sleep apnoea; she uses home oxygen at night only.
[INCOMING_NURSE] Does she use nasal prongs or a mask?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: A Mask. She has come in for further investigation. Her family are quite worried about her living alone, so she needs a referral to Social Work.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: okay, I’ll put the referral to the Social Worker this morning.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She’s been very confused. Yesterday she couldn’t remember her relatives when they visited and She’s still confused today, so there is no change in her level of confusion.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay, so this is her base line.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Yes, There’s also a query for a … “cut” assessment and a mini-mental assessment for Tim to review.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Do you mean an ACAT assessment plus a Mini-Mental (MMSE) for Tim?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Yes, that’s the request—ACAT and MMSE for Tim to review.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Got it. I’ll organise the MMSE and flag ACAT with Social Work, and I’ll message Tim.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Otherwise, no other changes. She is still confused.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Amanda, we’re going to keep you safe and comfortable. If you need anything, press the call bell here.
[PATIENT]: I… where am I?
[INCOMING_NURSE]: You’re in hospital, Amanda. We’re looking after you. We’ll stay close by. Don't get up and walk on your own as I don't want you to fall.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Anything else you’d like me to cover?
[INCOMING_NURSE]: I’ll set up the referrals now and keep an eye on her orientation and night oxygen needs.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Great. Thanks.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks, Amanda. I’ll be back shortly.

example.text:
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Good Morning. This is Pamela Harris Lee in bed 6. Pamela, this is Alex, the day nurse taking over from me.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Hi Pamela, nice to meet you. Is it okay if we do your bedside handover together?
[PATIENT]: Sure.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Pamela is 51 years old, admitted with an exacerbation of COPD. She’s a smoker and came in today with increased shortness of breath.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: I am just going to check your arm band, Thanks. Pamela, can you confirm your full name for me?
[PATIENT]: Pamela Harris Lee.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thank you. Any medication allergies?
[PATIENT]: No allergies that I know of.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She’s much the same as she was on arrival. She’s on her regular inhalers and nebulisers, and she’s pretty stable at the moment.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Any changes in observations or need for escalation?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: No changes. Observations are stable and there are no new concerns during my shift.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Is oxygen required?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Not at the moment she is maintaining her satuarations at 98% on room air with nebs/inhalers as charted.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Pamela, how are you feeling right now?
[PATIENT]: Still a bit short of breath, but better after the nebs.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay. I’ll make sure your inhalers and nebulisers are on time, and check in regularly with you let me know if you feel more short of breath.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: The plan for today is to continue regular puffers and nebs as charted, and  monitor her respiratory status and observations. She’s currently stable.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: I’ll review inhaler technique later and make sure she's comfortable. Pamela, press your call bell if your breathing worsens or you need anything.
[PATIENT]: Will do, thank you.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: All right, that’s everything from me.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks. I’ll take it from here.

example.text:
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Good Morning, Mr Hunt. I’m taking over your care now. We’ll just do a quick bedside handover with my colleague, okay?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Thanks. This is Abraham Hunt, 83 years old, under Dr Jamie.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Mr Hunt, could you confirm your name for me?
[PATIENT]: Abraham Hunt.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thank you. Any medication allergies that you know of? and when was the cannula inserted?
[PATIENT]: No, not that I know of, it was put in yesterday in ED.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He presented with chest pain, but it’s more likely not cardiac-related. He does have a history of a heart attack five years ago.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Any chest pain right now, Mr Hunt?
[PATIENT]: No, none at the moment.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Any shortness of breath?
[PATIENT]: No.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He’s stable. On a general diet, self-caring and ambulant on the ward. He’s on his regular puffers and nebs.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Noted. Any IV lines?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: No. Meds-wise, he’s also on Clexane daily.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: What’s the plan for today?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He’s awaiting the doctor’s review under and may need some follow up tests to see what is happening for you to come into hospital.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Mr Hunt, we’ll keep monitoring you. If that chest pain returns or anything changes, please press the call bell straight away.
[PATIENT]: Will do. Thank you.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks for the handover. I’ll check your obs shortly and make sure your puffers and nebs are on schedule.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Morning. This is Bed 2.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Hercules Kokinakis, he is 76, under Dr Kenzie.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Hi Hercules, I’m the incoming nurse my name is Brad. We’re just doing your handover.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: He’s on a ventilator, so communication will be limited—Hercules, if you’re comfortable, give me a thumbs up?
[PATIENT]: Gives a small nod.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He was found by his wife on the floor at home, unconscious and not breathing so she rang the ambulance.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He has a past history of type 2 diabetes, sleep apnoea, and is overweight.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He is currently stable but ventilated, he needs regular position changes to prevent a pressure area.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Any immediate concerns overnight?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: No acute issues flagged. Monitoring ongoing while ventilated, his bp is 180/82 HR 56.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: What it is the plan for today? 
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Physio is to start next shift.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He is waiting for an ICU bed—transfer as soon as there’s a room available, this can be arranged sooner if he deteriorates, but he is currently stable.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay so physio will start on the next shift, and pending ICU bed. I’ll continue close monitoring and liaise with bed management.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Hercules, we’ll keep you comfortable and keep you updated. If you’re in any pain, try to nod and we’ll assess.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: That’s everything from me. Anything to add, Hercules?
[PATIENT]: Shakes head.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks. I’ll take it from here.

example.text:
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Good Morning, Neil. I’m Sam, I’ll be looking after you today. Is it okay if we do your handover at the bedside?
[PATIENT]: Sure.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Thanks, Neil. Hi Sam. This is Bed 4, Neil Paganus, He is 39 years old.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Neil, can you tell me your full name, please?
[PATIENT]: Neil Paganus.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thank you. I'll  just check your medication charts and IV cannula to make sure they are up to date. 

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Neil came in with severe allergy symptoms and a history of asthma. He had difficulty breathing and was very chesty on arrival. He was febrile with a temperature of 38.8.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: We took blood cultures and gave paracetamol with good effect. The medical team has reviewed; Dr Tim was informed, and antibiotics have been changed as per their plan.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: So the Blood cultures are still pending?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Yes.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: How’s your breathing now, Neil?
[PATIENT]: Better than before, still a bit tight but improving.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay, we’ll keep a close eye on that.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He’s on a general diet, self-caring, and ambulant.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Any other concerns overnight?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: No acute events after paracetamol. He’s been comfortable and mobilizing independently.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Great. Any specific precautions?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Just routine observations, we are monitoring his temperature and respiratory status, and giving the antibiotics as charted.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Neil, we’ll keep checking your observations and let you know when any results come back. Please use the call bell if your breathing worsens or you feel unwell.
[PATIENT]: Will do, thanks.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks for the handover.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: No worries. I’m off—call me if you need anything before I go.

[PATIENT]: No, I’m okay. Thank you.

example.text:
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Hi Jerry, I’m Taylor, I’ll be looking after you today. I’m just going to get handover from Sam who’s been on the night shift, is that okay?
[PATIENT]: Sure.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Morning, Taylor. This is Jerry Reed.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Hi Jerry.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Jerry is 45, under Dr. Harry. He has a history of congestive cardiac failure, IHT, hypertension, type 2 diabetes (diet controlled), and depression.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He came in with bilateral leg oedema. He has a right AV graft and is scheduled for haemodialysis tomorrow afternoon.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay, he has a right AV graft in situ, and dialysis is tomorrow afternoon.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He’s on a 1.2-litre fluid restriction with daily weights. He’s on IV furosemide. We also need lying and standing blood pressures to be done this afternoon.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: I’ll do the blood pressure this afternoon. 
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He’s for the diabetic educator tomorrow at 1 pm, and there’s a family meeting booked for Thursday at 2:30 pm.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay, diabetic educator tomorrow 1300, family meeting Thursday 1430.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Jerry’s been very demanding and at times aggressive with staff. We’ve been using clear communication and de-escalation; please approach with firm boundaries and escalate if safety is a concern.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks for the heads-up. Jerry, we want to make sure you feel heard and comfortable. If something’s not working for you, let us know and we’ll do our best within the plan we have.
[PATIENT]: Okay.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Any pain or shortness of breath right now?
[PATIENT]: Just the legs feel heavy. No chest pain.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: That’s consistent with earlier. No other acute issues noted on my shift.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Great. I’ll double-check your weight, input/output, and confirm your dialysis booking for tomorrow afternoon. I’ll also set reminders for the orthostatic BPs.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Perfect. That’s everything from me.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks, Sam. Jerry, I’ll be back shortly with your morning plan and to talk through the fluid restriction and what to expect today.
[PATIENT]: Thanks.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Hi Cecilia, I’m Sam, I’ll be looking after you today. Is it okay if we do your handover at the bedside?
[PATIENT]: Yes, that’s fine.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: We’re in Bed 1, This is Cecilia Ramos, 38, under Dr Willow. Admitted with a renal obstruction; Her full history is in the notes.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: I’ll just check your ID band, Cecilia… great, thank you.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She had a CT scan last week. She has been charted pain medication. 
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Cecilia, how’s your pain right now?
[PATIENT]: It’s still there, but manageable.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay, I’ll keep an eye on your timing and make sure you’re comfortable.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: The Plan is to discharge at the end of this week and Follow‑up with Dr Willow one week post discharge and book a renal outpatients appointment for two weeks after discharge. The discharge summary is at the front of the notes.
[INCOMING_NURSE]:  Are we just waiting on medications to go home?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Yes we are waiting for the discharge meds from pharmacy.
[INCOMING_NURSE]:  I’ll chase those up.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She’s quite anxious. Family is in attendance at the moment.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Cecilia, we’ll keep you updated about timing and the medications so you’re not left wondering.
[PATIENT]: I appreciate that. I’ve been a bit worried.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Of course. I’ll check in regularly, and if anything changes with your pain or you have questions, press the call bell.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: That’s everything from me. See you tomorrow.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks. Anything else you’d like us to know or anything you need right now, Cecilia?
[PATIENT]: No, that’s all. Thank you.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Great—I’ll follow up pharmacy and be back shortly.

[INCOMING_NURSE]:  Good Morning, Nicholas. I’m Mia, I’ll be looking after you today. I’m just getting handover from Sam, the night nurse. Is that okay?
[PATIENT]: Sure, that’s fine.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Thanks, Nicholas. So, this is Room 3, Bed 1: Nicholas Ferrer, 64, under Dr. Morris. Admitted with painful urination, haematuria, and reported fevers prior to admission.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Hi Nicholas, could you tell us your full name, please, while I check your ID band?
[PATIENT]: Nicholas Ferrer.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thank you, matches the band. 
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He has a history of hypertension, type 2 diabetes diet-controlled, depression, GORD, and gout.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Observations have been stable and he’s afebrile on the ward.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Any pain right now, Nicholas?
[PATIENT]: A bit of burning when I go, but otherwise okay.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: We’ll keep an eye on that and use what’s charted if you need it.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: We still need to collect a urine MCS, and he is for bloods tomorrow morning as per the request.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: I’ll make sure the urine specimen pot is at the bedside and labelled, and we’ll collect it next when you void. 
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He’s still for the team review today.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Under Dr. Morris so we’ll watch for their round.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He's on a diabetic diet and his BGLs are BD as ordered.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Any issues with intake?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He is Eating and drinking fine and is self-caring and can mobilise independently.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Great. No falls risk concerns noted?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: No, he’s steady.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Nicholas, the plan from here isto get a urine sample off to the lab, check your sugars twice today, and the medical team will review you. If the burning worsens or you notice more blood, please buzz us straight away.
[PATIENT]: Okay, will do.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Call bell’s within reach here—do you have it?
[PATIENT]: Yep, right here.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: That’s everything from me.
[INCOMING_NURSE] Nicholas, can I get you anything before we head off?
[PATIENT]: I’m fine, thanks.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: I’ll be back shortly to set up the specimen and do your obs.

example.text:
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Good Morning, Marco. I’m the incoming nurse. I’ll just get bedside handover from my colleague and then we’ll check in with you.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Hi, Marco. He’s Bed 6 in Room 1, under Dr. Sun. Admitted with nephrolithiasis—kidney stones.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks. Marco, can you confirm your full name and age?
[PATIENT]: Marco Calasso, 40.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Great, thank you.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He has a background history of depression and asthma. He’s on both oral and IV antibiotics. He’s for a Lithotripsy with Dr. Sun next week.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay what day?

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Wednesday, I think. His Main issues overnight have been pain, it has been severe—he’s rating it 10 out of 10 despite regular Panadol, plus PRN Morphine and Endone.
[PATIENT]: It’s been really strong, yeah.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay, Marco, we’ll reassess that right after handover.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He still has haematuria. He also had nausea and vomiting; we gave IV metoclopramide with good effect—settled the nausea.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Good to hear the antiemetic helped.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]:He has one IV cannula in the right hand— the site is patent and intact.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: I’ll check the site and flush after handover.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Blood pressure has been elevated; up to 180/86 the team are aware. He’s on FBC and a general diet.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: FBC as in fluid balance charting?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Yes—fluid balance charting. General diet otherwise.
[INCOMING_NURSE]:  Any other tests or bookings today?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: There may be something pending for tomorrow; waiting on the team to confirm. Lithotripsy is next week.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: So the plan is to continue oral and IV antibiotics, monitor hematuria and fluid balance, manage pain—consider review since he’s still 10/10—and keep an eye on the BP; team already informed.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Agreed.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Marco, is there anything else worrying you right now?
[PATIENT]: Mostly the pain. The nausea’s better.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay. We’ll be back shortly to reassess your pain and give what’s due. Use your call bell if it spikes again.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Thanks, Marco. I’ll leave you with the day team now.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Good Morning, Harry. I’m Mia, I’ll be looking after you today. I’m just getting handover from Sam.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Hi. This is Harry Lewis in bed 2, 36 years old, under Dr. Gaylor. He was admitted with pyelonephritis.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Hi Harry, could you confirm your name for me while I check your wristband?
[PATIENT]: Harry Lewis.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Great, thank you.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]:  Bloods were taken this morning; the results are still pending.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Any other changes noted overnight? Pain, fever, new symptoms?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: No other changes noted.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Phil came in by ambulance four days ago for thrombolytic therapy. He’s got a long history of cardiac problems of about 14 years.

[PATIENT]: Samuel Edmond.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks—I’ll just check your wristband for your details. All good.

[PATIENT]: Sure.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: That’s everything from me.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks, Dan. Samuel, buzz if you need anything.
[PATIENT]: Will do.

example.text:
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Good Morning, Natalie. I’m Sam, I’ll be looking after you today. I’m just going to get bedside handover from Alex, is that okay?
[PATIENT]: That’s fine.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Thanks, Natalie. So, this is room 4, bed 5. Patient is Natalie Caricas, 79 years old, under Dr Ross.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She came in with stomach pain and jaundice. She has a Past history  which includes diabetes and obesity. She’s reporting feeling tired, a bit dizzy, and low in mood.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Her urine has been very dark; I’ve sent a urine MCS. She arrived on the ward about three hours ago. Admission obs and paperwork are done, and her observations have been stable since arrival.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Great. Any mobility concerns?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Yes, she needs assistance with walking. I’ve flagged that she should be referred to physio.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay so shes an assist with all mobilising and falls precautions in place.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: yes. Diet-wise she’s on a diabetic diet. We’re doing QID BGL monitoring, and she’s on oral hypoglycemics.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: QID BGLs and oral hypos—no insulin charted?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: No insulin charted at present.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Pain management?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She’s charted for Endone and morphine PRN for pain. She’s been uncomfortable, so please assess and medicate as needed.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Will do.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She hasn’t been seen by the medical team yet; she’s here for further investigation. We’re awaiting the team review under Dr Ross.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks. Natalie, how are you feeling right now—any pain, dizziness, or nausea?
[PATIENT]: My belly still hurts, and I feel a bit light-headed. I’m also just… a bit down.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thank you for telling us. I’ll check your observations now, get you some pain relief if it’s due, and make sure you’re safe when you get up. We’ll also let the doctors know how you’re feeling when they come.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: That’s everything from me: her obs are stable a urine MCS was sent, she's an assist with mobility, and is on adiabetic diet with QID BGLs, oral hypoglycemics, PRN Endone/morphine charted, awaiting team review and physio referral.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Perfect. Natalie, your call bell is within reach—please ring before you get out of bed and we’ll come and help.
[PATIENT]: Okay, thank you.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks, Alex. I’ll take it from here.

example.text:
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Good Morning, Hildy. I'm just here with my colleague to do bedside handover, is that okay?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Hi there. This is Hildy Hutter in room 4, bed 6, under Dr. Forbes.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Hildy, could you tell us your full name and date of birth?
[PATIENT]: Oh… I’m waiting for the bus, dear.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: That’s alright, Hildy. We’ll just check your ID band and IV medications.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Hildy is a lovely 91-year-old lady admitted with a urinary tract infection.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She’s currently on IV antibiotics. The doctors have also charted oral antibiotics to commence tomorrow.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay, so the IV ABs running now at 100ml per hour.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Yes they are Running as charted; the next dose due as per the medication times. I’ve signed the last dose.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She’s very confused today. Observations have been stable, but she is febrile.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: otherwise she has stable obs but with a temperature. I’ll keep monitoring and encourage fluids as appropriate.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Thank you. No other acute issues to flag at the moment.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Hildy, you might feel a bit warm—we’re keeping a close eye on you. Are you in any pain right now?
[PATIENT]: I think I should be going home soon… where’s my coat?
[INCOMING_NURSE]: We’ll help you with that later. For now you’re safe here. The call bell is right by your hand, and we’ll be popping in regularly.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Plan for the shift: continue IV antibiotics as charted, monitor temperature and observations, and oral antibiotics to start tomorrow. We’ll also keep reorienting and maintain falls precautions given the confusion.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Perfect. Anything else you need before I head off, Hildy?
[PATIENT]: A cup of tea… maybe.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: I’ll check what you can have and come right back.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks for the handover.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: No worries. I’m off. See you both later.

example.text:
[AMBULANCE OFFICER]: Hi, I’m handing over Mr. George Wallace, 78 years old. He was brought in from home following a GP request for review. He has a background of depression and possible early dementia and is now presenting with acute confusion and agitation.
[ED NURSE]: What’s been happening?
[AMBULANCE OFFICER]: Over the past week he’s become increasingly withdrawn, refusing meals, and expressing low mood. His GP prescribed diazepam 5 mg twice daily for agitation, but since then he’s become more confused and restless. Today he was found wandering at home, disoriented. His wife reports he’s barely eaten in two days.
[ED NURSE]: Any observations or assessments done?
[AMBULANCE OFFICER]: Yes, 4AT score is 7. Vitals: BP 134/76, HR 88, Temp 37.4°C, RR 18, SpO₂ 96% RA. He’s alert but disoriented to time and place. No obvious injuries. BGL 6.1.
[ED NURSE]: Current medications?
[AMBULANCE OFFICER]: On diazepam with last dose last night, sertraline 50 mg mane. No known allergies.
[ED NURSE]:Thanks. Anything else I should know?
[AMBULANCE OFFICER]: He’s been responding to reorientation during transport when and has settled when we’ve told him his name, the date and time, and that he’s on his way to the hospital. He remains settled but may need constant observations. Oh his wife is the EPOA.
[ED NURSE]: Got it. We’ll continue orientation and arrange close monitoring until the team reviews.
